No change to previous policy.  The following preventative measures for the elderly continue to be conducted:  - Recommendations and communications for active/healthy living and staying indoors targeted towards senior citizens.  - Monthly evaluation of preventive and infection control measures within long-term care homes.  - Comprehensive information and training material for LTC staff and ownership including donning/doffing of PPE, systematic area zoning within facilities, and procedures involving admissions, discharge, hygiene and garbage.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210814031717/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/hukushi_kaigo/kaigo_koureisha/index.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210814031656/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/hukushi_kaigo/kaigo_koureisha/taisakumatome_13635.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210814031814/https://kayoinoba.mhlw.go.jp/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210814031746/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/0000121431_00252.htmlGovernment of Japan will be distributing more than 36 million doses beginning August 31 to prefectures (expected to completely be distributed by early October), in hopes of fully vaccinating all individuals over 12. In addition, AstraZeneca vaccine will be delivered to the six prefectures that have been declared a state of emergency from August 16.  Occupational vaccinations for workplaces and universities continue to be conducted throughout August. Vaccinations for the elderly population continue to be conducted at mass vaccination sites in Tokyo and Osaka, in addition to targeted healthcare workers who have already had access since February. Vaccinations without reservations for ages below 65 are being considered in downtown Tokyo. AstraZeneca has been made available for public vaccination for individuals above age 40. Those who are allergic to Pfizer or Moderna under the age of 40 may also receive AstraZeneca.  As of August 6 the official numbers are as follows, 45.7% of the total population have one dose, 32.7% have two doses. In the elderly population over 65, 87.3% have one dose, 80% have two doses.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210814031839/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/0000121431_00218.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210814031850/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/special/coronavirus/vaccine/japan_2021/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210814031926/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/special/coronavirus/vaccine/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210716220739/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210716/k10013143611000.htmlNo change to previous policy. The wearing of facial masks continue to be recommended.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210814031524/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/0000121431_00094.htmlSmall-cluster contact tracing continues to be manually conducted, in addition to the utilization of the COVID-19 Contact-Confirming Application (COCOA).    https://web.archive.org/web/20210814030441/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210813/k10013200341000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210814031057/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210810/k10013193591000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210814030232/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/covid-19/kansenkakudaiboushi-iryouteikyou.htmlNo change to previous policy.   Antigen tests are limitedly available to eligible cluster cases when fast results are requested for a large number of people. Due to potential inaccuracies, negative antigen tests will be re-tested via PCR.  PCR tests are conducted at medical institutions designated by prefectures for returnee patients, outpatients, and when a doctors deems the testing be necessary.  In some areas, with the cooperation of regional medical associations, "regional outpatient/examination center" have been set up to carry out intensive examinations and to determine testing. While symptomatic individuals are typically recommended, PCR testing can be made available at the discretion of certain institutions if a health centre or doctor determines an individual a close contact, even if asymptomatic. For PCR tests carried out at these institutions, patients will not be responsible for the cost of the tests. Patients however, are responsible for the initial consultation fee.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210814025922/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/0000121431_00132.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210814030151/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/kenkou_iryou/dengue_fever_qa_00004.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210725204229/https://omorimachi.com/pcr/timing/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210725204321/https://www.aozoracl.com/coronavirus_pcrComprehensive public information about COVID-19 continues to be disseminated by the government.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210814025632/https://corona.go.jp/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210814025731/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/special/coronavirus/data-widget/ (Dashboard properly loads in the non-archived version)  https://web.archive.org/web/20210731043406/https://www.stopcovid19.jp/ (Data properly loads in the non-archived version)No change to previous policy. New debt relief application deadlines for July-Sept 2021 have been set for December 31, 2021 (support document revised as of Aug 5).  The Japan Ministry of Health, Labour, and Welfare continues to provide debt relief: loans for small-lot emergency funds and comprehensive unemployment funds are provided at interest-free and payments may be deferred up to one year. Housing security loans are available for those at risk of losing housing: rent payments may be deferred up to 9-months with evidence of employment search. Property tax exemption may be available for applicants facing declining income or unemployment due to the pandemic. For single-parent households, family housing support loan is available interest-free with the possibility of repayment exemption. Interviews for single-parent households will be conducted to understand their living conditions, motivation for employment, efforts to acquire qualifications, etc. A policy is also in place for the deferment for payments of national taxes.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210814025056/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/covid-19/kurashiyashigoto.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210809030410/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/content/10900000/000622924.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210814025250/https://corona.go.jp/action/No change to previous policy. New subsidy application deadlines for July-Sept 2021 have been set for December 31, 2021 (support document revised as of Aug 5).  The Japan Ministry of Health, Labour, and Welfare continues to provide financial support in the forms of: employment subsidies to encourage business owners to maintain employees, leave of absence due to COVID-19 infection, living expenses for leave of absence or the unemployed, and special support for low-income child-rearing households.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210814025056/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/covid-19/kurashiyashigoto.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210809030410/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/content/10900000/000622924.pdfNo change to previous policy. New subsidy application deadlines for July-Sept 2021 have been set for December 31, 2021 (support document revised as of Aug 5).  The Japan Ministry of Health, Labour, and Welfare continues to provide financial support in the forms of: employment subsidies to encourage business owners to maintain employees, leave of absence due to COVID-19 infection, living expenses for leave of absence or the unemployed, and special support for low-income child-rearing households.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210814025056/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/covid-19/kurashiyashigoto.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210809030410/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/content/10900000/000622924.pdf

According to reports and interviews from prefectures of Tokyo and Saitama, due to the high number of infections, close contact tracing has been overwhelmed and efforts have shifted to targeted/priority settings such as schools or elderly facilities.  For other prefectures, small-cluster contact tracing continues to be manually and comprehensively conducted, in addition to the utilization of the COVID-19 Contact-Confirming Application (COCOA).    https://web.archive.org/web/20210814022625/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210814/k10013201711000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210814030232/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/covid-19/kansenkakudaiboushi-iryouteikyou.html

No change to previous policy.  The following preventative measures for the elderly continue to be conducted:  - Recommendations and communications for active/healthy living and staying indoors targeted towards senior citizens.  - Monthly evaluation of preventive and infection control measures within long-term care homes.  - Comprehensive information and training material for LTC staff and ownership including donning/doffing of PPE, systematic area zoning within facilities, and procedures involving admissions, discharge, hygiene and garbage.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210823031427/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/hukushi_kaigo/kaigo_koureisha/index.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210823031445/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/hukushi_kaigo/kaigo_koureisha/taisakumatome_13635.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210823031511/https://kayoinoba.mhlw.go.jp/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210823031518/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/0000121431_00252.htmlOccupational vaccinations for workplaces, universities, and public schools continue to be conducted throughout August. However, by the end of July it was found that more than 420 venues had to be cancelled due to delays in receiving vaccines from the government. Only 2408 venues and 46% of the applications were able to start vaccinations by August 15, equivalent to about 3.1 million people. However, the country expects by the end of August to the beginning of September, supply can be distributed to all venues that have been applied and approved.    The Japanese government is also considering the third booster dose vaccinations for healthcare workers at the 8-month mark following recommendations by the United States' CDC, which if approved, would begin in October.    From August 18, Tokyo will be expanding the number of those eligible to be vaccinated at the mass vaccination sites in Tokyo for those who work in schools, waste disposal facilities, transportation services, and personal care services such as barbers or salons. From August 27, Tokyo will be beginning the vaccination for young people near Shibuya station for those age 16-39 who live, work, or attend school in Tokyo.  AstraZeneca has been made available for public vaccination for individuals above age 40. Those who are allergic to Pfizer or Moderna under the age of 40 may also receive AstraZeneca. In addition, any health hazard as a result of the vaccine may receive relief as covered under the Japan Immunization Law.    As of August 20 the official numbers are as follows, 51.3% of the total population (includes children under the age eligible for vaccination) have one dose, 39.7% have two doses. Patients however, are responsible for the initial consultation fee.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210823025915/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/0000121431_00132.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210823025923/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/kenkou_iryou/dengue_fever_qa_00004.htmlComprehensive public information about COVID-19 continues to be disseminated by the government.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210823025255/https://corona.go.jp/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210814025731/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/special/coronavirus/data-widget/ (Dashboard properly loads in the non-archived version)  https://web.archive.org/web/20210731043406/https://www.stopcovid19.jp/ (Data properly loads in the non-archived version)No change to previous policy. New debt relief application deadlines for July-Nov 2021 have been set for December 31, 2021 (support document revised as of Aug 18).  The Japan Ministry of Health, Labour, and Welfare continues to provide debt relief: loans for small-lot emergency funds and comprehensive unemployment funds are provided at interest-free and payments may be deferred up to one year. Housing security loans are available for those at risk of losing housing: rent payments may be deferred up to 9-months with evidence of employment search. Property tax exemption may be available for applicants facing declining income or unemployment due to the pandemic. For single-parent households, family housing support loan of upto 40,000 yen for 12 months is available interest-free with the possibility of repayment exemption. Interviews for single-parent households will be conducted to understand their living conditions, motivation for employment, efforts to acquire qualifications, etc. A policy is also in place for the deferment for payments of national taxes.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210823024151/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/covid-19/kurashiyashigoto.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210823024219/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/content/10900000/000622924.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210823024645/https://corona.go.jp/action/No change to previous policy. New subsidy application deadlines for July-Nov 2021 have been set for December 31, 2021 (support document revised as of Aug 18).  The Japan Ministry of Health, Labour, and Welfare continues to provide financial support in the forms of: employment subsidies to encourage business owners to maintain employees, leave of absence due to COVID-19 infection, living expenses for leave of absence or the unemployed, and special support for low-income child-rearing households. New priority measures apply to the prefectures of Miyagi, Yamanashi, Toyama, Gifu, Mie, Okayama, Hiroshima, Kagawa, Ehime and Kagoshima.    Okinawa will also continue their extended state of emergency until September 12, where events with a maximum of 1,000 people at 50% venue capacity may proceed to be held. Events with no spectators, however, are being recommended.  All other prefectures under emergency orders, events with a maximum of 5,000 people at a 50% venue capacity may proceed to be held.    For other prefectures under priority or no measures, if the gathering does not require loud cheering, the event may proceed at 100% facility capacity for a maximum of 5,000 people or less. For gatherings with loud cheering, the event may proceed at 50% facility capacity for a maximum of 5,000 people or less. All events must end at 9pm in prefectures with priority measures. Restaurants may service customers provided restaurants follow shorten business hours from 5am to 8pm. All other businesses should also operate between 5am to 8pm.  For prefectures under priority measures: within cities, local governments request all businesses operate between 5am to 8pm. Outsidecities, all businesses are requested to operate between 5am to 9pm. Many schools are preparing for infection control measures to resume after the summer vacation including thermography cameras and acrylic board to assist with physical distancing. Yokohama City has announced it will temporarily close elementary and junior high schools to delay reopening after summer vacation past August 29. A further announcement will be made beginning next week with details on the closure. In Kanagawa Prefecture, Sagamihara City and Kawasaki City have also decided to temporarily close municipal elementary and junior high schools throughout the month of August.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210822072727/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210821/k10013215561000.html

No change to previous policy.  The following preventative measures for the elderly continue to be conducted:  - Recommendations and communications for active/healthy living and staying indoors targeted towards senior citizens.  - Monthly evaluation of preventive and infection control measures within long-term care homes.  - Comprehensive information and training material for LTC staff and ownership including donning/doffing of PPE, systematic area zoning within facilities, and procedures involving admissions, discharge, hygiene and garbage.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210823031427/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/hukushi_kaigo/kaigo_koureisha/index.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210823031445/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/hukushi_kaigo/kaigo_koureisha/taisakumatome_13635.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210826203428/http://kayoinoba.mhlw.go.jp/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210823031518/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/0000121431_00252.htmlOccupational vaccinations for workplaces, universities, and public schools continue to be conducted throughout August. The country expects by the end of August to the beginning of September, supply can be distributed to all venues that have been applied and approved. However, due to the recall of contaminated Moderna vaccines, planned vaccinations at the Agency for Cultural Affairs and some ANA and Japan Airline venues have been cancelled.    On August 25, Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare has notified local governments nationwide to provide priority vaccination to pregnant women. Pregnant women in Tokyo are eligible for priority vaccinations and may begin booking reservations through local clinics and the Tokyo mass vaccination site.  On August 27, Tokyo begins walk-in (no reservation required) vaccinations for young people near Shibuya station for those age 16-39 who live, work, or attend school in Tokyo. However, the lines on the first day of youth vaccination was exceedingly long.    AstraZeneca has been made available for public vaccination for individuals above age 40. Those who are allergic to Pfizer or Moderna under the age of 40 may also receive AstraZeneca. In addition, any health hazard as a result of the vaccine may receive relief as covered under the Japan Immunization Law.  As of August 27 the official numbers are as follows, 54.5% of the total population (includes children under the age eligible for vaccination) have one dose, 43.5% have two doses. In the elderly population over 65, 89.3% have one dose, 86.9% have two doses.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210827204819/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210826/k10013224021000.html (Moderna)  https://web.archive.org/web/20210827204600/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210826/k10013225121000.html (Moderna)  https://web.archive.org/web/20210827205504/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210825/k10013221291000.html (pregnant women)  https://web.archive.org/web/20210827205052/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210825/k10013222301000.html (pregnant women)  https://web.archive.org/web/20210827204911/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210826/k10013225191000.html (pregnant women)  https://web.archive.org/web/20210827205607/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210827/k10013226311000.html (youth vaccination)  https://web.archive.org/web/20210827210022/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/0000121431_00218.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210827203645/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/special/coronavirus/vaccine/japan_2021/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210827203711/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/special/coronavirus/vaccine/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210716220739/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210716/k10013143611000.htmlNo change to previous policy. There continues to be a reduction in ability to conduct full close contact tracing in Tokyo and Saitama due to the high number of infections. Typically due to potential inaccuracies, negative antigen tests are re-tested via PCR. Okinawa will continue to close public facilities effective until Sep 12.  For prefectures under emergency orders: nightclubs, cabarets, karaoke parlors and bars not licensed as a restaurant must close. Restaurants may service customers provided restaurants follow shorten business hours from 5am to 8pm. All other businesses and events should also operate between 5am to 8pm.  For prefectures under priority measures: within cities, local governments request all businesses operate between 5am to 8pm. Meeting halls, theatres, recreational facilities, places of tourism or leisure all must comply within these guidelines for shorten business hours.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210827180513/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210825/k10013221651000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210827180753/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210823013806/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/_res/projects/default_project/_page_/001/014/544/20210817.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210827181418/https://www.pref.okinawa.lg.jp/site/chijiko/koho/corona/documents/0825taisyohoshin.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210823125017/https://www.pref.kumamoto.jp/soshiki/30/104632.htmlIn Osaka, local governments in Neyagawa Citiy or Suita City have delayed reopening or moved classes online for municipal elementary and junior high schools by one week from August 23 to 27. In Kanagawa, the cities of Yokohama, Kawasaki, Sagamihara, and Yamato has temporarily closed schools after summer vacation. Minamiashigara city's elementary and junior high schools will temporarily close until September 3 and conduct online classes until September 10. Between September 1 to 12, attendance for in-person classes in middle and high school will be staggered to 1 or 2 days a week depending on the grade. No change to previous policy.  The following preventative measures for the elderly continue to be conducted:  - Recommendations and communications for active/healthy living and staying indoors targeted towards senior citizens.  - Monthly evaluation of preventive and infection control measures within long-term care homes.  - Comprehensive information and training material for LTC staff and ownership including donning/doffing of PPE, systematic area zoning within facilities, and procedures involving admissions, discharge, hygiene and garbage.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210906201717/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/hukushi_kaigo/kaigo_koureisha/index.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210906201844/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/hukushi_kaigo/kaigo_koureisha/taisakumatome_13635.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210906202018/http://kayoinoba.mhlw.go.jp/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210906202053/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/0000121431_00252.htmlOccupational vaccinations for workplaces, universities, and public schools continue throughout the month of September. However, due to a manufacturing error, contamination of metal particulates have been found within Moderna vaccines and 1.63 million doses sent to 901 venues have been recalled and may temporarily delay vaccination efforts.  Pregnant women continue to be prioritized at government mass vaccination sites and hospital vaccination clinics. Due to high demands for youth vaccination in Tokyo, the Shibuya non-appointment vaccination centre will begin to conduct an online lottery starting September 4.    AstraZeneca has been made available for public vaccination for individuals above age 40. Those who are allergic to Pfizer or Moderna under the age of 40 may also receive AstraZeneca. In addition, any health hazard as a result of the vaccine may receive relief as covered under the Japan Immunization Law.  As of September 3 the official numbers are as follows, 58.0% of the total population (includes children under the age eligible for vaccination) have one dose, 47.1% have two doses. In the elderly population over 65, 89.1% have one dose, 87.1% have two doses.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210905232409/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210902/k10013238291000.html (Moderna)  https://web.archive.org/web/20210905233353/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210902/k10013239651000.html (pregnant women)  https://web.archive.org/web/20210905234206/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210903/k10013240771000.html (youth vaccination)  https://web.archive.org/web/20210905234236/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/0000121431_00218.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210905234311/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/special/coronavirus/vaccine/japan_2021/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210905234523/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/special/coronavirus/vaccine/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210716220739/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210716/k10013143611000.htmlNo change to previous policy. The wearing of facial masks in Japan is widely spread and continues to be recommended by the government.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210906201506/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/0000121431_00094.htmlNo change to previous policy. Due to the inability to conduct comprehensive contact tracing in Saitama, the prefecture is looking to offload tracing efforts to individual businesses and workplaces.  There continues to be a reduction in ability to conduct full close contact tracing in Tokyo and Saitama due to the high number of infections. Close contact tracing has been overwhelmed and efforts have shifted to targeted/priority settings such as schools or elderly facilities.    For other prefectures, small-cluster contact tracing continues to be manually and comprehensively conducted, in addition to the utilization of the COVID-19 Contact-Confirming Application (COCOA).    https://web.archive.org/web/20210906201209/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210901/k10013237791000.html (Saitama)  https://web.archive.org/web/20210827204135/https://www.nikkei.com/article/DGXZQOCC153FC0V10C21A8000000/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210827204246/https://www.nikkan-gendai.com/articles/view/life/293435  https://web.archive.org/web/20210823030440/https://www.yomiuri.co.jp/national/20210821-OYT1T50023/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210814022625/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210814/k10013201711000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210823030717/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/covid-19/kansenkakudaiboushi-iryouteikyou.htmlNo change to previous policy.  800,000 antigen test kits have been distributed to kindergartens, elementary, and middle schools for the start of the fall semester.  Antigen tests are limitedly available to eligible cluster cases when fast results are requested for a large number of people. Typically due to potential inaccuracies, negative antigen tests are re-tested via PCR.    PCR tests are conducted at medical institutions designated by prefectures for returnee patients, outpatients, and when a doctors deems the testing be necessary.  In some areas, with the cooperation of regional medical associations, "regional outpatient/examination center" have been set up to carry out intensive examinations and to determine testing. While symptomatic individuals are typically recommended, PCR testing can be made available at the discretion of certain institutions if a health centre or doctor determines an individual a close contact, even if asymptomatic. For PCR tests carried out at these institutions, patients will not be responsible for the cost of the tests. Patients however, are responsible for the initial consultation fee.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210827194425/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210827/k10013227701000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210906200422/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/0000121431_00132.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210906200732/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/kenkou_iryou/dengue_fever_qa_00004.htmlComprehensive public information about COVID-19 continues to be disseminated by the government.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210906200256/https://corona.go.jp/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210814025731/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/special/coronavirus/data-widget/ (Dashboard properly loads in the non-archived version)  https://web.archive.org/web/20210731043406/https://www.stopcovid19.jp/ (Data properly loads in the non-archived version)No change to previous policy. New debt relief application deadlines for July-Nov 2021 have been set for December 31, 2021 (support document revised as of Aug 18).  The Japan Ministry of Health, Labour, and Welfare continues to provide debt relief: loans for small-lot emergency funds and comprehensive unemployment funds are provided at interest-free and payments may be deferred up to one year. Housing security loans are available for those at risk of losing housing: rent payments may be deferred up to 9-months with evidence of employment search. Property tax exemption may be available for applicants facing declining income or unemployment due to the pandemic. For single-parent households, family housing support loan of upto 40,000 yen for 12 months is available interest-free with the possibility of repayment exemption. Interviews for single-parent households will be conducted to understand their living conditions, motivation for employment, efforts to acquire qualifications, etc. A policy is also in place for the deferment for payments of national taxes.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210906195720/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/covid-19/kurashiyashigoto.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210827190619/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/content/10900000/000622924.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210906195944/https://corona.go.jp/action/No change to previous policy. On September 4, mass vaccination centres in Tokyo and Osaka will begin inoculations for younger generations (age 18-39). In the month of September, the vaccination sites have set a quota to vaccinate 30,000 young people and priority slots for the younger generation can be booked online beginning 6pm on September 3. The government has also announced the mass vaccination centres will extend operations until at least the end of November in order to accelerate vaccination efforts. The Government of Japan continues to encourage residents to stay home and avoid areas or activities of high risk for infection.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210910005559/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210910013547/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/_res/projects/default_project/_page_/001/015/484/20210909/20210909.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210910013317/https://www.pref.okinawa.lg.jp/site/chijiko/koho/corona/documents/0909taishohoshin.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210906191253/https://www.pref.okinawa.lg.jp/site/chijiko/koho/corona/documents/0825eigo.pdfAll public transportation continues to remain in operation.  Tokyo Metro has posted alternative commuter office hours for the Tokyo state of emergency.  Regular service continues on Japan Rail with heightened prevention measures including increase ventilation, physical distancing, disinfection, wearing of masks, and preventing passengers from rotating seats.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210910010637/https://www.tokyometro.jp/index.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210906193947/https://www.tokyometro.jp/info/210446.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210906193324/https://www.westjr.co.jp/info/corona_taisaku.htmlNo change to previous policy.  In Tokyo, the cities of Chofu, Tama, and Hino have temporarily suspended in-person learning and will hold online classes for the fall semester until September 11.  In Kanagawa, Minamiashigara city's elementary and junior high schools will temporarily close until September 3 and conduct online classes until September 10. Between September 1 to 12, attendance for in-person classes in middle and high school will be staggered to 1 or 2 days a week depending on the grade.  There are a number of other municipality school closures and delay of in-person learning in the prefectures of Fukuoka, Saitama, Chiba, Ibaraki, Tochigi (until Sept 12 in Mibu City), and Gunma.    For schools that have not suspended in-person learning, such as those in Setagaya ward (Tokyo), Oita and Yokohama prefecture, students in elementary and junior high schools have begun staggering attendance by grades or groups to a few days per week to reduce the number of students on-site at any one moment.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210910012808/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210907/k10013248741000.html (staggered classes)  https://web.archive.org/web/20210906001811/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210901/k10013236401000.html (staggered classes)  https://web.archive.org/web/20210827174444/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210824/k10013220081000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210827175625/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210826/k10013224221000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210826231400/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210824/k10013220931000.html

No change to previous policy.  The following preventative measures for the elderly continue to be conducted:  - Recommendations and communications for active/healthy living and staying indoors targeted towards senior citizens.  - Monthly evaluation of preventive and infection control measures within long-term care homes.  - Comprehensive information and training material for LTC staff and ownership including donning/doffing of PPE, systematic area zoning within facilities, and procedures involving admissions, discharge, hygiene and garbage.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210910194814/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/hukushi_kaigo/kaigo_koureisha/index.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210910194934/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/hukushi_kaigo/kaigo_koureisha/taisakumatome_13635.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210910195004/http://kayoinoba.mhlw.go.jp/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210906202053/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/0000121431_00252.htmlNo change to previous policy. The wearing of facial masks in Japan is widely spread and continues to be recommended by the government.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210910194649/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/0000121431_00094.htmlNo change to previous policy. Due to the inability to conduct comprehensive contact tracing in Saitama, the prefecture is looking to offload tracing efforts to individual businesses and workplaces.  There continues to be a reduction in ability to conduct full close contact tracing in Tokyo and Saitama due to the high number of infections. Close contact tracing has been overwhelmed and efforts have shifted to targeted/priority settings such as schools or elderly facilities.    For other prefectures, small-cluster contact tracing continues to be manually and comprehensively conducted, in addition to the utilization of the COVID-19 Contact-Confirming Application (COCOA).    https://web.archive.org/web/20210910194431/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210910/k10013254271000.html (example of cluster tracing in Nagasaki)  https://web.archive.org/web/20210910194558/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210907/k10013248021000.html (example of cluster tracing in Gifu)  https://web.archive.org/web/20210906201209/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210901/k10013237791000.html (Saitama)  https://web.archive.org/web/20210827204135/https://www.nikkei.com/article/DGXZQOCC153FC0V10C21A8000000/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210827204246/https://www.nikkan-gendai.com/articles/view/life/293435  https://web.archive.org/web/20210823030440/https://www.yomiuri.co.jp/national/20210821-OYT1T50023/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210814022625/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210814/k10013201711000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210910194722/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/covid-19/kansenkakudaiboushi-iryouteikyou.htmlNo change to previous policy.  800,000 antigen test kits have been distributed to kindergartens, elementary, and middle schools for surveillance purposes for the start of the fall semester.  Antigen tests are limitedly available to eligible cluster cases when fast results are requested for a large number of people. Typically due to potential inaccuracies, negative antigen tests are re-tested via PCR.    PCR tests are conducted at medical institutions designated by prefectures for returnee patients, outpatients, and when a doctors deems the testing be necessary. In some areas, with the cooperation of regional medical associations, "regional outpatient/examination center" have been set up to carry out intensive examinations and to determine testing. While symptomatic individuals are typically recommended, PCR testing can be made available at the discretion of certain institutions if a health centre or doctor determines an individual a close contact, even if asymptomatic. For PCR tests carried out at these institutions, patients will not be responsible for the cost of the tests. Patients however, are responsible for the initial consultation fee.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210827194425/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210827/k10013227701000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210910194221/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/0000121431_00132.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210910194243/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/kenkou_iryou/dengue_fever_qa_00004.htmlComprehensive public information about COVID-19 continues to be disseminated by the government.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210910193801/https://corona.go.jp/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210814025731/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/special/coronavirus/data-widget/ (Dashboard properly loads in the non-archived version)  https://web.archive.org/web/20210731043406/https://www.stopcovid19.jp/ (Data properly loads in the non-archived version)No change to previous policy. New debt relief application deadlines for July-Nov 2021 have been set for December 31, 2021 (support document revised as of Sep 9).  The Japan Ministry of Health, Labour, and Welfare continues to provide debt relief: loans for small-lot emergency funds and comprehensive unemployment funds are provided at interest-free and payments may be deferred up to one year. Housing security loans are available for those at risk of losing housing: rent payments may be deferred up to 9-months with evidence of employment search. Property tax exemption may be available for applicants facing declining income or unemployment due to the pandemic. For single-parent households, family housing support loan of upto 40,000 yen for 12 months is available interest-free with the possibility of repayment exemption. Interviews for single-parent households will be conducted to understand their living conditions, motivation for employment, efforts to acquire qualifications, etc. A policy is also in place for the deferment for payments of national taxes.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210910192158/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/covid-19/kurashiyashigoto.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210910192507/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/content/10900000/000622924.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210910192615/https://corona.go.jp/action/No change to previous policy. New subsidy application deadlines for July-Nov 2021 have been set for December 31, 2021 (support document revised as of Sep 9).  The Japan Ministry of Health, Labour, and Welfare continues to provide financial support in the forms of: employment subsidies to encourage business owners to maintain employees, leave of absence due to COVID-19 infection, living expenses for leave of absence or the unemployed, and special support for low-income child-rearing households for a maximum of 50,000 yen per child. Employment subsidies have a maximum of 15,000 yen per day per person.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210910192158/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/covid-19/kurashiyashigoto.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210910192507/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/content/10900000/000622924.pdfNo change to previous policy. New subsidy application deadlines for July-Nov 2021 have been set for December 31, 2021 (support document revised as of Sep 9).  The Japan Ministry of Health, Labour, and Welfare continues to provide financial support in the forms of: employment subsidies to encourage business owners to maintain employees, leave of absence due to COVID-19 infection, living expenses for leave of absence or the unemployed, and special support for low-income child-rearing households for a maximum of 50,000 yen per child. Employment subsidies have a maximum of 15,000 yen per day per person.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210910192158/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/covid-19/kurashiyashigoto.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210910192507/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/content/10900000/000622924.pdf

On Sep 9, the government announces emergency and priority measures have been extended until Sep 30.  State of emergency measures extended from Sep 12 to Sep 30: Hokkaido, Miyagi, Gifu, Aichi, Mie, Shiga, Okayama, Hiroshima, Okinawa, Tokyo, Saitama, Chiba, Kanagawa, Osaka, Ibaraki, Tochigi, Gunma, Shizuoka, Kyoto, Hyogo, Fukuoka.  Prority measures extended from Sep 12 to Sep 30: Miyazaki, Kumamoto, Kagawa, Kagoshima.  Priority measures will lift on Sep 12 for: Toyama, Yamanashi, Ehime, Kochi, Saga, and Nagasaki.    Okinawa will continue their extended state of emergency until September 30, where events with a maximum of 1,000 people at 50% venue capacity may proceed to be held. Events with no spectators, however, are being recommended.  All other prefectures under emergency orders, events with a maximum of 5,000 people at a 50% venue capacity may proceed to be held.    For other prefectures under priority or no measures, if the gathering does not require loud cheering, the event may proceed at 100% facility capacity for a maximum of 5,000 people or less. For gatherings with loud cheering, the event may proceed at 50% facility capacity for a maximum of 5,000 people or less. All events must end at 9pm in prefectures with priority measures.  Local governments continue to encourage residents to stay home and to avoid going to crowded places or engaging in high risk activities.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210910005628/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210909/k10013250961000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210910005559/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210910013547/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/_res/projects/default_project/_page_/001/015/484/20210909/20210909.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210910013317/https://www.pref.okinawa.lg.jp/site/chijiko/koho/corona/documents/0909taishohoshin.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210906191253/https://www.pref.okinawa.lg.jp/site/chijiko/koho/corona/documents/0825eigo.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210910015844/https://www.pref.kumamoto.jp/soshiki/30/104632.htmlOn Sep 9, the government announces emergency and priority measures have been extended until Sep 30. Okinawa will continue to close public facilities effective until Sep 30.  For prefectures under emergency orders: nightclubs, cabarets, karaoke parlors and bars not licensed as a restaurant must close. Restaurants may service customers provided restaurants follow shorten business hours from 5am to 8pm. All other businesses and events should also operate between 5am to 8pm.  For prefectures under priority measures: Alcohol restrictions have been lifted allowing alcohol to be served until 7:30pm. Local governments also request all businesses operate between 5am to 9pm with the exception of restaurants which should operate between 5am to 8pm. Meeting halls, theatres, recreational facilities, places of tourism or leisure all must comply within these guidelines for shorten business hours.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210910005628/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210909/k10013250961000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210910005559/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210910013547/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/_res/projects/default_project/_page_/001/015/484/20210909/20210909.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210910013317/https://www.pref.okinawa.lg.jp/site/chijiko/koho/corona/documents/0909taishohoshin.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210906191253/https://www.pref.okinawa.lg.jp/site/chijiko/koho/corona/documents/0825eigo.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210910015844/https://www.pref.kumamoto.jp/soshiki/30/104632.htmlThe Tokyo Metropolitan Board of Education has decided to hold classes for Tokyo Metropolitan High School online on all weekdays and consecutive holidays in the latter half of September (dubbed "Silver Week"). Decentralized school attendance and staggered school attendance have been carried out since the end of summer vacation, but measures will be further strengthened during "Silver Week" in the latter half of September. Specifically, during the period, all classes will be held online on weekdays: 21st and 22nd, and 24th. Holidays are on Mon Sep 20th and Thu Sep 23rd.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210910022721/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210909/k10013252101000.html

On September 10, priority vaccination appointments for 18-39 year olds begin to open at the Osaka mass vaccination site with 6000 reservation slots filling up in 7 minutes after the booking system opens. Inoculation efforts for 18-39 year olds in the Tokyo and Osaka venues will be held until September 25 for a total of over 30,000 vaccinations for the younger generation.  In Shizuoka City, priority vaccinations also began being held for children ages 12+ and parents; for a total vaccination quota of more than 2,860 people.    Those who are eligible to be inoculated at the mass vaccination sites include 65+, pregnant women, and ages 18-39.  The government has announced that vaccine supply for 90% of those over 12 years old to be vaccinated twice will be available by early October. The government is also working on foundations of a certificate of vaccination.    As of Sep 10, 61.9% of the entire population (including children under age eligible for vaccination) has received at least one dose, and 49.8% of entire population has received two doses.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210910195220/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210910/k10013253861000.html (Osaka mass vaccination)  https://web.archive.org/web/20210905234805/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210902/k10013239891000.html (Tokyo mass vaccination)  https://web.archive.org/web/20210910195804/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210910/k10013253171000.html (Shizuoka)  https://web.archive.org/web/20210910195836/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/special/coronavirus/vaccine/japan_2021/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210910200346/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/special/coronavirus/vaccine/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210910200626/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/0000121431_00218.html

State of emergency measures extended from Sep 12 to Sep 30: Hokkaido, Miyagi, Gifu, Aichi, Mie, Shiga, Okayama, Hiroshima, Okinawa, Tokyo, Saitama, Chiba, Kanagawa, Osaka, Ibaraki, Tochigi, Gunma, Shizuoka, Kyoto, Hyogo, Fukuoka.  Prority measures extended from Sep 12 to Sep 30: Miyazaki, Kumamoto, Kagawa, Kagoshima.  Priority measures will lift on Sep 12 for: Toyama, Yamanashi, Ehime, Kochi, Saga, and Nagasaki.    Okinawa will continue their extended state of emergency until September 30, where events with a maximum of 1,000 people at 50% venue capacity may proceed to be held. Events with no spectators, however, are being recommended.  All other prefectures under emergency orders, events with a maximum of 5,000 people at a 50% venue capacity may proceed to be held.    For other prefectures under priority or no measures, if the gathering does not require loud cheering, the event may proceed at 100% facility capacity for a maximum of 5,000 people or less. For gatherings with loud cheering, the event may proceed at 50% facility capacity for a maximum of 5,000 people or less. All events must end at 9pm in prefectures with priority measures. Okinawa will continue to close public facilities effective until Sep 30.  For prefectures under emergency orders: nightclubs, cabarets, karaoke parlors and bars not licensed as a restaurant must close. Restaurants may service customers provided restaurants follow shorten business hours from 5am to 8pm. All other businesses and events should also operate between 5am to 8pm.  For prefectures under priority measures: Alcohol restrictions have been lifted allowing alcohol to be served until 7:30pm. Local governments also request all businesses operate between 5am to 9pm with the exception of restaurants which should operate between 5am to 8pm. Meeting halls, theatres, recreational facilities, places of tourism or leisure all must comply within these guidelines for shorten business hours.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210918001040/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210910005628/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210909/k10013250961000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210910013547/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/_res/projects/default_project/_page_/001/015/484/20210909/20210909.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210910013317/https://www.pref.okinawa.lg.jp/site/chijiko/koho/corona/documents/0909taishohoshin.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210918004444/https://www.pref.okinawa.lg.jp/site/chijiko/koho/corona/documents/0909eigo.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210910015844/https://www.pref.kumamoto.jp/soshiki/30/104632.html

On September 12, Joso city in Ibaraki prefecture begin focusing mass vaccination efforts towards foreign residents due to issues with language barrier and dissemination of information.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210917235830/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210912/k10013256271000.html

On September 13, healthcare workers in Toyanaka city, Osaka begin the dispatch of "vaccine cars," vehicles promoting vaccination and pop-up clinics towards younger generation in smaller neighbourhoods.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210918000405/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210913/k10013257101000.htmlSchools in many regions have resumed in-person learning, however, school attendance is largely part-time through staggering grades or shortening classes to reduce the number of students on-site at any one time. All other days of the week for students are spent in online lessons.  For many wards and prefectures, online schooling is also a voluntary option available to students and parents during the state of emergency.  From September 20 to 26, all public schools in Tokyo Metropolitan Area announced there will be a temporary suspension of in-person learning during Silver Week.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210910022721/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210909/k10013252101000.html (Silver Week suspension in Tokyo)  https://web.archive.org/web/20210918025123/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210913/k10013256991000.html (summary of school attendance in Tokyo's 23 wards)

On September 17, in order to promote uptake of vaccination in individuals 39 years old and younger, Minato ward in Tokyo will be operating a weekend midnight vaccination clinic every Friday. This late-night operating clinic will allow those in the workforce who are worried about taking time off work due to potential next day side effects to be inoculated.    https://archive.vn/FHmXG

No change to previous policy.  The following preventative measures for the elderly continue to be conducted:  - Recommendations and communications for active/healthy living and staying indoors targeted towards senior citizens.  - Monthly evaluation of preventive and infection control measures within long-term care homes.  - Comprehensive information and training material for Long Term Care staff and ownership including donning/doffing of PPE, systematic area zoning within facilities, and procedures involving admissions, discharge, hygiene and garbage.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210924214541/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/hukushi_kaigo/kaigo_koureisha/index.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210924214547/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/hukushi_kaigo/kaigo_koureisha/taisakumatome_13635.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210924214614/http://kayoinoba.mhlw.go.jp/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210924214621/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/0000121431_00252.htmlNo change to previous policy. The wearing of facial masks in Japan is widely spread and continues to be recommended by the government.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210924214431/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/0000121431_00094.htmlIn Osaka due to current high rates of infection, it may take an upwards of 4 days to be contacted by designated contact tracers. There continues to be a reduction in ability to conduct full close contact tracing in Tokyo and Saitama due to the high number of infections. Close contact tracing has been overwhelmed and efforts have shifted to targeted/priority settings such as schools or elderly facilities.  For other prefectures, small-cluster contact tracing continues to be manually and comprehensively conducted, in addition to the utilization of the COVID-19 Contact-Confirming Application (COCOA).    https://web.archive.org/web/20211008205930/https://www.kobe-np.co.jp/news/tanba/202109/0014706179.shtml (evidence of contact tracing in Kobe)  https://web.archive.org/web/20210924214016/https://www.hokkoku.co.jp/articles/tym/534241 (evidence of contact tracing in Toyama)  https://web.archive.org/web/20210924214131/https://www.sanin-chuo.co.jp/articles/-/98731 (evidence of contact tracing in Tottori)  https://web.archive.org/web/20210924213853/https://www.sankeibiz.jp/macro/news/210907/mca2109070604003-n1.htm (Osaka)  https://web.archive.org/web/20210906201209/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210901/k10013237791000.html (Saitama)  https://web.archive.org/web/20210823030440/https://www.yomiuri.co.jp/national/20210821-OYT1T50023/ (Tokyo & Saitama)  https://web.archive.org/web/20210814022625/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210814/k10013201711000.html (Tokyo)  https://web.archive.org/web/20210924214251/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/covid-19/kansenkakudaiboushi-iryouteikyou.html (Government testing information)No change to previous policy.  800,000 antigen test kits have been distributed to kindergartens, elementary, and middle schools for surveillance purposes for the start of the fall semester.  Antigen tests are limitedly available to eligible cluster cases when fast results are requested for a large number of people. Typically due to potential inaccuracies, negative antigen tests are re-tested via PCR.    PCR tests are conducted at medical institutions designated by prefectures for returnee patients, outpatients, and when a doctors deems the testing be necessary. In some areas, with the cooperation of regional medical associations, "regional outpatient/examination center" have been set up to carry out intensive examinations and to determine testing. While symptomatic individuals are typically recommended, PCR testing can be made available at the discretion of certain institutions if a health centre or doctor determines an individual a close contact, even if asymptomatic. For PCR tests carried out at these institutions, patients will not be responsible for the cost of the tests. Patients however, are responsible for the initial consultation fee.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210827194425/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210827/k10013227701000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210924213307/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/0000121431_00132.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210924213329/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/kenkou_iryou/dengue_fever_qa_00004.htmlComprehensive public information about COVID-19 continues to be disseminated by the government.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210924210105/https://corona.go.jp/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210924210337/https://corona.go.jp/dashboard/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210814025731/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/special/coronavirus/data-widget/ (Dashboard properly loads in the non-archived version)  https://web.archive.org/web/20210731043406/https://www.stopcovid19.jp/ (Data properly loads in the non-archived version)No change to previous policy. New debt relief application deadlines for July-Nov 2021 have been set for December 31, 2021 (support document revised as of Sep 9).  The Japan Ministry of Health, Labour, and Welfare continues to provide debt relief: loans for small-lot emergency funds and comprehensive unemployment funds are provided at interest-free and payments may be deferred up to one year. Housing security loans are available for those at risk of losing housing: rent payments may be deferred up to 9-months with evidence of employment search. Property tax exemption may be available for applicants facing declining income or unemployment due to the pandemic. For single-parent households, family housing support loan of upto 40,000 yen for 12 months is available interest-free with the possibility of repayment exemption. Interviews for single-parent households will be conducted to understand their living conditions, motivation for employment, efforts to acquire qualifications, etc. A policy is also in place for the deferment for payments of national taxes.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210924205751/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/covid-19/kurashiyashigoto.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210910192507/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/content/10900000/000622924.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210924205939/https://corona.go.jp/actionNo change to previous policy. State of emergency measures apply to: Hokkaido, Gifu, Aichi, Mie, Shiga, Hiroshima, Okinawa, Tokyo, Saitama, Chiba, Kanagawa, Osaka, Ibaraki, Tochigi, Gunma, Shizuoka, Kyoto, Hyogo, Fukuoka.  Priority measures apply to: Ishikawa, Fukushima, Kumamoto, Kagawa, Kagoshima, Miyazaki, Miyagi, Okayama.    Okinawa will continue to close public facilities effective until Sep 30.  For prefectures under emergency orders: nightclubs, cabarets, karaoke parlors and bars not licensed as a restaurant must close. Restaurants may service customers provided restaurants follow shorten business hours from 5am to 8pm. All other businesses and events should also operate between 5am to 8pm.  For prefectures under priority measures: Alcohol restrictions have been lifted allowing alcohol to be served until 7:30pm. Local governments also request all businesses operate between 5am to 9pm with the exception of restaurants which should operate between 5am to 8pm. Meeting halls, theatres, recreational facilities, places of tourism or leisure all must comply within these guidelines for shorten business hours.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210924203224/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210910013547/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/_res/projects/default_project/_page_/001/015/484/20210909/20210909.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210924203712/https://www.pref.okinawa.lg.jp/site/chijiko/koho/corona/documents/0923taisyohoshin.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210918004444/https://www.pref.okinawa.lg.jp/site/chijiko/koho/corona/documents/0909eigo.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210910015844/https://www.pref.kumamoto.jp/soshiki/30/104632.htmlDuring "Silver Week", all public schools in Tokyo Metropolitan Area from September 20 to 26 will be temporarily closed to in-person learning. Students are expected to return on Sep 27.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210910022721/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210909/k10013252101000.html (Silver Week suspension in Tokyo)

In Shinjuku Ward, the number of mass inoculation venues, which was 17 as of July, has been reduced to 10 due to the decrease in supply. To accomodate for the higher population of young people (18-39 year olds) in certain areas within Tokyo, the Japanese government will be redirecting supply from other locales to necessary wards in Tokyo.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210924175631/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210922/k10013272411000.html

No change to previous policy. Last report on provisional measures in nursing homes was published as of September 10, 2021.  The following preventative measures for the elderly continue to be conducted:  - Recommendations and communications for active/healthy living and staying indoors targeted towards senior citizens.  - Monthly evaluation of preventive and infection control measures within long-term care homes.  - Comprehensive information and training material for Long Term Care staff and ownership including donning/doffing of PPE, systematic area zoning within facilities, and procedures involving admissions, discharge, hygiene and garbage.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211003210029/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/hukushi_kaigo/kaigo_koureisha/index.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003210056/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/hukushi_kaigo/kaigo_koureisha/taisakumatome_13635.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003210231/http://kayoinoba.mhlw.go.jp/No change to previous policy. The wearing of facial masks in Japan is wide spread and continues to be recommended by the government. Masks should also be worn in schools by students and faculty members, and should only be removed when eating or partaking in physical activities.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211003190427/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003210417/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/0000121431_00094.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003210650/https://www.mext.go.jp/a_menu/coronavirus/mext_00020.htmlNo change to previous policy.  Antigen tests are limitedly available to eligible cluster cases when fast results are requested for a large number of people. Typically due to potential inaccuracies, negative antigen tests are re-tested via PCR.    PCR tests are conducted at medical institutions designated by prefectures for returnee patients, outpatients, and when a doctors deems the testing be necessary. In some areas, with the cooperation of regional medical associations, "regional outpatient/examination center" have been set up to carry out intensive examinations and to determine testing. While symptomatic individuals are typically recommended, PCR testing can be made available at the discretion of certain institutions if a health centre or doctor determines an individual a close contact, even if asymptomatic. For PCR tests carried out at these institutions, patients will not be responsible for the cost of the tests. Patients however, are responsible for the initial consultation fee.    PCR tests, antigen tests, and antibody tests may be requested for asymptomatic individuals for the purposes of travel will however, be charged by laboratory facilities.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211003204849/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/0000121431_00132.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210924213329/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/kenkou_iryou/dengue_fever_qa_00004.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003205333/https://jp.usembassy.gov/services/pcr-testing-facilities-in-japan/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003205304/https://hiro-clinic.jp/Comprehensive public information about COVID-19 continues to be disseminated by the government.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211003204637/https://corona.go.jp/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003204658/https://corona.go.jp/dashboard/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210814025731/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/special/coronavirus/data-widget/ (Dashboard properly loads in the non-archived version)  https://web.archive.org/web/20210731043406/https://www.stopcovid19.jp/ (Data properly loads in the non-archived version)No change to previous policy. New debt relief subsidy application deadlines for Nov 2021 to Dec 2021 have been set for February 28, 2022 (support document revised as of Oct 1).  The Japan Ministry of Health, Labour, and Welfare continues to provide debt relief: loans for small-lot emergency funds and comprehensive unemployment funds are provided at interest-free and payments may be deferred up to one year. Housing security loans are available for those at risk of losing housing: rent payments may be deferred up to 9-months with evidence of employment search. Property tax exemption may be available for applicants facing declining income or unemployment due to the pandemic. For single-parent households, family housing support loan of upto 40,000 yen for 12 months is available interest-free with the possibility of repayment exemption. Interviews for single-parent households will be conducted to understand their living conditions, motivation for employment, efforts to acquire qualifications, etc. A policy is also in place for the deferment for payments of national taxes.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211003203950/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/covid-19/kurashiyashigoto.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003204320/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/content/10900000/000622924.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003204607/https://corona.go.jp/actionNo change to previous policy. New unemployment subsidy application deadlines for Nov 2021 to Dec 2021 have been set for February 28, 2022 (support document revised as of Oct 1, p.34).  The Japan Ministry of Health, Labour, and Welfare continues to provide financial support in the forms of: employment subsidies to encourage business owners to maintain employees, leave of absence due to COVID-19 infection, living expenses for leave of absence or the unemployed, and special support for low-income child-rearing households for a maximum of 50,000 yen per child. Employment subsidies have a maximum of 15,000 yen per day per person.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211003203950/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/covid-19/kurashiyashigoto.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003204320/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/content/10900000/000622924.pdfNo change to previous policy. New unemployment subsidy application deadlines for Nov 2021 to Dec 2021 have been set for February 28, 2022 (support document revised as of Oct 1, p.34).  The Japan Ministry of Health, Labour, and Welfare continues to provide financial support in the forms of: employment subsidies to encourage business owners to maintain employees, leave of absence due to COVID-19 infection, living expenses for leave of absence or the unemployed, and special support for low-income child-rearing households for a maximum of 50,000 yen per child. Employment subsidies have a maximum of 15,000 yen per day per person.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211003203950/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/covid-19/kurashiyashigoto.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003204320/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/content/10900000/000622924.pdfBorder closure for entry into Japan continues to be in place. Travel for tourism and other short-term purposes remain restricted, while all Visa-free travel is suspended.  For travellers who are granted exceptional status for entry, various countries will have differing quarantine and testing requirements on arrival corresponding to country/region designation by variants of concern provided by the Japan Ministry of Foreign Affairs (latest list of specialty measures for regions is updated as of Sep 27).  To be eligible for a shortened quarantine period, Japan has so far designated only Pfizer, AstraZeneca, and Moderna as valid certificates of vaccination. All certificates must be issued by the public institution from government or country of origin, and must be written in either Japanese or English containing the following information: name, date of birth, vaccine name or manufacturer, vaccination date, dose. In addition, 14-days or more must have passed from the second dose date.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211003202905/https://jp.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003203427/https://www.anzen.mofa.go.jp/info/pcwideareaspecificinfo_2021C127.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003203141/https://www.anzen.mofa.go.jp/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003203912/https://www.anzen.mofa.go.jp/covid19/certificate_to_Japan.htmlNo change to previous policy. All public transportation continues to remain in operation.  Tokyo Metro is provided detailed information on congestion for each train line and train station at each hour.  Regular service continues on Japan Rail with heightened prevention measures including increase ventilation, physical distancing, disinfection, wearing of masks, and preventing passengers from rotating seats.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211003202429/https://www.tokyometro.jp/index.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003202730/https://tmap-sid.tokyometro.jp/o/view/index.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003202830/https://www.westjr.co.jp/info/corona_taisaku.html

As of September 26, at large scale vaccination sites in Tokyo and Osaka, there is surplus of vacant vaccination appointments available in the coming few weekdays for a total of 8100 spots still available for booking. The government is urging all residents above 18 years old to get vaccinated.  Priority vaccinations continue to be administered for junior high school students, high school students, and their families with children who are about to enter examination period. Priority vaccinations are also occurring for pregnant women and their families.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211002175553/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210925/k10013275931000.html (examinee vaccinations)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211002175629/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210925/k10013276631000.html (pregnancy vaccinations)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211002180024/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210927/k10013279131000.html (surplus appointments)

The a week suspension of in-person learning for students in the Metropolitan Tokyo area has ended and all classes have resumed inline with other prefectures across Japan.  The government of Japan has decided all emergency and priority measures will be lighted for all prefectures on October 1. Included, all schools across Japan currently stagger attendance by grades or classes will resume full capacity in-person learning on October 1. Continued focus on sanization, contact tracing within schools, and restrictions on club activities or school excursions will remain. Individual schools also have the jurisdiction to temporarily close due to infection outbreaks on a case-by-case basis.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210910022721/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210909/k10013252101000.html (Silver Week)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003032546/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210928/k10013280271000.html (Resumption of school)

Due to the continued surplus in vacant slots at mass vaccination sites in Tokyo and Osaka, the Japanese government has lifted restrictions for young people priority bookings. All residents age 16+ are able to begin booking at mass vaccination sites on September 30 for slots beginning October 4. For junior and high school students age 12+, reservations will begin October 1 for slots starting October 4.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211002181039/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210929/k10013283021000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211002181528/https://www.fukushihoken.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/iryo/kansen/coronavaccine/daikibosesshu.html

In Osaka, an announcement was made that all Osakan mass vaccination sites will begin administering walk-in vaccinations (no reservations required) for resident age 16+ beginning October 4.    As of Oct 1, 70.4% of the total population in Japan (including those under the eligible age for vaccination) have received their first dose, with 59.8% of the total population having received both doses.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211002182119/https://osaka-mvc.com/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211002182806/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/special/coronavirus/vaccine/The government continues to encourage residents to practice precautions moving between prefectures, particularly to and from areas of high infection rates and particularly for those unvaccinated.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211003190427/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/The government continues to encourage people to avoid dense crowds and situations of high risk for infection, to refrain for unnecessary movement to areas with high infection rates and to cooperate with the night-time business closures at 9:00PM.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211003190427/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/On October 1, Japan lifts emergency and priority measures for all prefectures and will undergo a precautionary period for one month. From Oct 1 to Oct 24, Tokyo will undergo a period with various lighter restrictions. For Okinawa, the precautionary period is between Oct 1 to Oct 31.    During the precautionary period, all events are asked to be completed by 9:00PM. For events involving loud events, capacity is limited to 50% of the venue capacity and not exceed an upper limit of 10,000 people. For events with no loud voices, 100% of the venue capacity may be used but not exceed an upper limit of 5,000 people. In Okinawa, loud events are limited to 50% venue capacity and must not exceed 5,000 people.  Businesses are asked to reduce the number of workers in the office by 70% through utilizing remote methods of work and to request employees finish work by 8:00PM. Drinking gatherings at bars are asked to to be limited to 4 people per group.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211003190427/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003193347/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210929/k10013281591000.html (restrictions in Kanto region)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003193702/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210928/k10013281561000.html (restrictioins in Tokyo)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003190552/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/_res/projects/default_project/_page_/001/015/636/20210928/torikumi.pdf (Tokyo)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003190640/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/_res/projects/default_project/_page_/001/015/638/20211001.pdf (Tokyo)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003190745/https://www.pref.okinawa.lg.jp/site/chijiko/koho/corona/documents/0928taisyohoshin_1.pdf (Okinawa)On October 1, Japan lifts emergency and priority measures for all prefectures and will undergo a precautionary period for one month. From Oct 1 to Oct 24, Tokyo will undergo a period with various lighter restrictions. For Okinawa, the precautionary period is between Oct 1 to Oct 31.    All businesses including bars and nightclubs are able to reopen provided businesses serving alcohol receives a certificate of inspection for infection control by the Ministry of Health, however karaoke equipment is requested not to be used. During the precautionary period, all businesses are requested to operate at shortened business hours between 5:00AM to 9:00PM with alcohol permitted to being served 11:00AM to 8:00PM (in Tokyo, Kanagawa, Saitama, and Okinawa). In Tochigi, alcohol may be served until 7:30PM; and in Okinawa, acohol may be served until 7:00PM. Many prefectures and school districts have been staggering class attendance but will begin in-person learning at full capacity due to measures being lifted. Schools are to continue undergoing stringent sanitation and infection prevention measures, restricting club activities with high risk of infection and suspension of all school excursions. Students with illness symptoms are not to attend schools. Individual schools may also have the jurisdiction to close due to in-school outbreaks on a school-by-school basis.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211003190427/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003191110/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211001/k10013285601000.html (resumption of classes)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003190946/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211001/k10013286091000.html (resumption of classes)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003190552/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/_res/projects/default_project/_page_/001/015/636/20210928/torikumi.pdf (Tokyo)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003190640/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/_res/projects/default_project/_page_/001/015/638/20211001.pdf (Tokyo)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003190745/https://www.pref.okinawa.lg.jp/site/chijiko/koho/corona/documents/0928taisyohoshin_1.pdf (Okinawa)

No change to previous policy. Last report on provisional measures in nursing homes was published as of September 10, 2021.  The following preventative measures for the elderly continue to be conducted:  - Recommendations and communications for active/healthy living and staying indoors targeted towards senior citizens.  - Monthly evaluation of preventive and infection control measures within long-term care homes.  - Comprehensive information and training material for Long Term Care staff and ownership including donning/doffing of PPE, systematic area zoning within facilities, and procedures involving admissions, discharge, hygiene and garbage.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211008212418/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/hukushi_kaigo/kaigo_koureisha/index.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008212436/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/hukushi_kaigo/kaigo_koureisha/taisakumatome_13635.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008212436/http://kayoinoba.mhlw.go.jp/On October 4, walk-in (no reservation) vaccinations begin for residents 16 years old and up at mass vaccination venues in Osaka Prefecture. Third dose vaccinations is being planned to begin in December 2021.
