While symptomatic individuals are typically recommended, PCR testing can be made available at the discretion of certain institutions if a health centre or doctor determines an individual a close contact, even if asymptomatic. For PCR tests carried out at these institutions, patients will not be responsible for the cost of the tests. Patients however, are responsible for the initial consultation fee.    PCR tests, antigen tests, and antibody tests may be requested for asymptomatic individuals for the purposes of travel will however, be charged by laboratory facilities.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211008192307/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211005/k10013291931000.html (rapid antigent testing in schools)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008205543/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/0000121431_00132.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008205549/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/kenkou_iryou/dengue_fever_qa_00004.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008205625/https://jp.usembassy.gov/services/pcr-testing-facilities-in-japan/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003205304/https://hiro-clinic.jp/Comprehensive public information about COVID-19 continues to be disseminated by the government.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211008205419/https://corona.go.jp/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008205414/https://corona.go.jp/dashboard/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210814025731/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/special/coronavirus/data-widget/ (Dashboard properly loads in the non-archived version)  https://web.archive.org/web/20210731043406/https://www.stopcovid19.jp/ (Data properly loads in the non-archived version)No change to previous policy. New debt relief subsidy application deadlines for Nov 2021 to Dec 2021 have been set for February 28, 2022 (support document revised as of Oct 1).  The Japan Ministry of Health, Labour, and Welfare continues to provide debt relief: loans for small-lot emergency funds and comprehensive unemployment funds are provided at interest-free and payments may be deferred up to one year. Housing security loans are available for those at risk of losing housing: rent payments may be deferred up to 9-months with evidence of employment search. Property tax exemption may be available for applicants facing declining income or unemployment due to the pandemic. For single-parent households, family housing support loan of upto 40,000 yen for 12 months is available interest-free with the possibility of repayment exemption. Interviews for single-parent households will be conducted to understand their living conditions, motivation for employment, efforts to acquire qualifications, etc. A policy is also in place for the deferment for payments of national taxes.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211008205132/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/covid-19/kurashiyashigoto.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008205138/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/content/10900000/000622924.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008205235/https://corona.go.jp/actionNo change to previous policy. New unemployment subsidy application deadlines for Nov 2021 to Dec 2021 have been set for February 28, 2022 (support document revised as of Oct 1, p.34).  The Japan Ministry of Health, Labour, and Welfare continues to provide financial support in the forms of: employment subsidies to encourage business owners to maintain employees, leave of absence due to COVID-19 infection, living expenses for leave of absence or the unemployed, and special support for low-income child-rearing households for a maximum of 50,000 yen per child. Employment subsidies have a maximum of 15,000 yen per day per person.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211008205132/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/covid-19/kurashiyashigoto.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008205138/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/content/10900000/000622924.pdfNo change to previous policy. Employment subsidies have a maximum of 15,000 yen per day per person.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211008205132/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/covid-19/kurashiyashigoto.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008205138/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/content/10900000/000622924.pdfBorder closure for entry into Japan continues to be in place. Travel for tourism and other short-term purposes remain restricted, while all Visa-free travel is suspended.  For travellers who are granted exceptional status for entry, various countries will have differing quarantine and testing requirements on arrival corresponding to country/region designation by variants of concern provided by the Japan Ministry of Foreign Affairs (latest list of specialty measures for regions is updated as of Sep 27).  To be eligible for a shortened quarantine period, Japan has so far designated only Pfizer, AstraZeneca, and Moderna as valid certificates of vaccination. All certificates must be issued by the public institution from government or country of origin, and must be written in either Japanese or English containing the following information: name, date of birth, vaccine name or manufacturer, vaccination date, dose. In addition, 14-days or more must have passed from the second dose date.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211008204034/https://jp.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008204749/https://www.mofa.go.jp/mofaj/files/100238774.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008204828/https://www.anzen.mofa.go.jp/info/pcwideareaspecificinfo_2021C127.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008204046/https://www.anzen.mofa.go.jp/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003203912/https://www.anzen.mofa.go.jp/covid19/certificate_to_Japan.htmlThe government continues to encourage residents to practice precautions moving between prefectures, particularly to and from areas of high infection rates and particularly for those unvaccinated.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211008202753/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/The government continues to encourage people to avoid dense crowds and situations of high risk for infection, to refrain for unnecessary movement to areas with high infection rates and to cooperate with the night-time business closures at 9:00PM.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211008202753/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/No change to previous policy. From Oct 1 to Oct 24, Tokyo will undergo a period with various lighter restrictions. For Okinawa, the precautionary period is between Oct 1 to Oct 31.    During the precautionary period, all events are asked to be completed by 9:00PM. For events involving loud events, capacity is limited to 50% of the venue capacity or an upper limit of 10,000 people. For events with no loud voices, 100% of the venue capacity may be used but not exceed an upper limit of 5,000 people. In Tokyo and Okinawa, events are limited to 50% venue capacity and must not exceed 5,000 people. Schools have all resumed in-person learning at full capacity due to measures being lifted. No change to previous policy. Last report on provisional measures in nursing homes was published as of October 5, 2021.  The following preventative measures for the elderly continue to be conducted:  - Recommendations and communications for active/healthy living and staying indoors targeted towards senior citizens.  - Monthly evaluation of preventive and infection control measures within long-term care homes.  - Comprehensive information and training material for Long Term Care staff and ownership including donning/doffing of PPE, systematic area zoning within facilities, and procedures involving admissions, discharge, hygiene and garbage.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211017201732/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/hukushi_kaigo/kaigo_koureisha/index.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211017201817/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/hukushi_kaigo/kaigo_koureisha/taisakumatome_13635.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211017201826/http://kayoinoba.mhlw.go.jp/No change to previous policy. The wearing of facial masks in Japan is wide spread and continues to be recommended by the government. Masks should also be worn in schools by students and faculty members, and should only be removed when eating or partaking in physical activities.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211017023524/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211017201616/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/0000121431_00094.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211017201638/https://www.mext.go.jp/a_menu/coronavirus/mext_00020.htmlNo change to previous policy.  There is no evidence limitations for close contact tracing has fully resumed in Tokyo and Saitama. For many wards in Tokyo, close contact tracing has been overwhelmed and efforts have shifted to targeted/priority settings such as schools or elderly facilities and also have shifted focus in making sure those severely ill are properly traced.  For other prefectures, small-cluster contact tracing continues to be manually and comprehensively conducted, in addition to the utilization of the COVID-19 Contact-Confirming Application (COCOA).    https://web.archive.org/web/20211017195316/https://www.m3.com/news/open/iryoishin/973681 (Tokyo wards)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211017201311/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/lnews/okinawa/20211014/5090015934.html (evidence of contact tracing in Okinawa)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211017201411/https://www.yomiuri.co.jp/local/osaka/news/20211004-OYTNT50138/ (evidence of Hirakata, Osaka preparing for more streamlined contact tracing efforts in the event of a new wave)  https://web.archive.org/web/20210823030440/https://www.yomiuri.co.jp/national/20210821-OYT1T50023/ (Tokyo & Saitama)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211017201307/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/covid-19/kansenkakudaiboushi-iryouteikyou.htmlNo change to previous policy.  Antigen tests are limitedly available to eligible cluster cases when fast results are requested for a large number of people, e.g. schools. Typically due to potential inaccuracies, negative rapid antigen tests are re-tested via PCR.    PCR tests are conducted at medical institutions designated by prefectures for returnee patients, outpatients, and when a doctors deems the testing be necessary. In some areas, with the cooperation of regional medical associations, "regional outpatient/examination center" have been set up to carry out intensive examinations and to determine testing. While symptomatic individuals are typically recommended, PCR testing can be made available at the discretion of certain institutions if a health centre or doctor determines an individual a close contact, even if asymptomatic. For PCR tests carried out at these institutions, patients will not be responsible for the cost of the tests. Patients however, are responsible for the initial consultation fee. All businesses including bars and nightclubs are able to reopen provided businesses serving alcohol receives a certificate of inspection for infection control by the Ministry of Health, however karaoke equipment is requested not to be used. During the precautionary period, all businesses are requested to operate at shortened business hours between 5:00AM to 9:00PM with alcohol permitted to being served 11:00AM to 8:00PM (in Tokyo, Kanagawa, Saitama, and Okinawa). In Tochigi, alcohol may be served until 7:30PM; and in Okinawa, acohol may be served until 7:00PM.  Businesses are asked to reduce the number of workers in the office by 70% through utilizing remote methods of work and to request employees finish work by 8:00PM.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211017023524/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003193347/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210929/k10013281591000.html (restrictions in Kanto region)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003193702/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210928/k10013281561000.html (restrictions in Tokyo)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003190552/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/_res/projects/default_project/_page_/001/015/636/20210928/torikumi.pdf (Tokyo)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008200105/https://www.pref.okinawa.lg.jp/site/chijiko/koho/corona/documents/1007taishohousin.pdf (Okinawa)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008200827/https://www.pref.okinawa.lg.jp/site/chijiko/koho/corona/documents/0928eigo.pdf (Okinawa)No change to previous policy as Japan lifts emergency and priority measures for all prefectures and continues undergoing a precautionary period for one month. From Oct 1 to Oct 24, Tokyo will undergo a period with various lighter restrictions. For Okinawa, the precautionary period is between Oct 1 to Oct 31.    Schools have all resumed in-person learning at full capacity due to measures being lifted. Schools are to continue undergoing stringent sanitation and infection prevention measures, restricting club activities with high risk of infection and suspension of all school excursions. Increased ventilation measures and distribution of antigen test kits will also continue to be conducted. Students with illness symptoms are not to attend schools. Individual schools may also have the jurisdiction to close due to in-school outbreaks on a school-by-school basis.    There are recent examples of individual school closures as a result of outbreaks in Agano City, Niigata and Fukui City, Fukui.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211017023958/https://www.niikei.jp/227863/ (Agano City)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211017024018/https://www.fukui-tv.co.jp/?post_type=fukui_news&p=143499 (Fukui City)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211017023524/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008192307/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211005/k10013291931000.html (school measures)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003190552/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/_res/projects/default_project/_page_/001/015/636/20210928/torikumi.pdf (Tokyo)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008200105/https://www.pref.okinawa.lg.jp/site/chijiko/koho/corona/documents/1007taishohousin.pdf (Okinawa)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008200827/https://www.pref.okinawa.lg.jp/site/chijiko/koho/corona/documents/0928eigo.pdf (Okinawa)

On Oct 15, the Ministry of Health, Labor and Welfare will allow men in their teens and 20s to receive the Pfizer vaccine over concerns for myocarditis in response to guidelines from other countries. Those who received Moderna for their first dose, may also mix vaccines and receive Pfizer for their second dose if they so choose.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211017231042/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/special/coronavirus/vaccine/japan_2021/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211018003512/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211013/k10013306041000.htmlOn Oct 15, as a result of the Ministry of Health, Labor and Welfare approving the sale of rapid antigen testing for the general public nationwide, rapid antigen tests begin being sold in pharmacies. All purchasers are to sign a consent form with a pharmacist explaining the technology and in the case of a positive test, all individuals must seek medical attention from appropriate authorities.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211017225754/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211015/k10013309151000.htmlOn Oct 15, requests for shorten business hours at restaurants and bars have been lifted for the following prefectures: Hiroshima, Gifu, and Fukuoka.  Remote working whenever possible continues to be encouraged by the federal government.    For all other prefectures, businesses are requested to operate at shortened business hours between 5:00AM to 9:00PM with alcohol permitted to being served 11:00AM to 8:00PM (in Tokyo, Kanagawa, Saitama, and Okinawa). In Tochigi, alcohol may be served until 7:30PM; and in Okinawa, acohol may be served until 7:00PM. Businesses have also been asked to reduce the number of workers in the office by 70% through utilizing remote methods of work and to request employees finish work by 8:00PM.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211017023524/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211017222328/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211015/k10013308261000.html (Hiroshima, Gifu, Fukuoka)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003193347/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210929/k10013281591000.html (restrictions in Kanto region)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003193702/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210928/k10013281561000.html (restrictions in Tokyo)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003190552/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/_res/projects/default_project/_page_/001/015/636/20210928/torikumi.pdf (Tokyo)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008200105/https://www.pref.okinawa.lg.jp/site/chijiko/koho/corona/documents/1007taishohousin.pdf (Okinawa)

No change to previous policy. Last report on provisional measures in nursing homes was published as of October 5, 2021.  The following preventative measures for the elderly continue to be conducted:  - Recommendations and communications for active/healthy living and staying indoors targeted towards senior citizens.  - Monthly evaluation of preventive and infection control measures within long-term care homes.  - Comprehensive information and training material for Long Term Care staff and ownership including donning/doffing of PPE, systematic area zoning within facilities, and procedures involving admissions, discharge, hygiene and garbage.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211023070848/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/hukushi_kaigo/kaigo_koureisha/index.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211023070854/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/hukushi_kaigo/kaigo_koureisha/taisakumatome_13635.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211023070910/http://kayoinoba.mhlw.go.jp/No change to previous policy.  Vaccination continues to be available and administered for all individuals age 12+ at the appropriate mass vaccination or muncipal vaccination sites.  Men in their teens and 20s to vaccinate may receive the Pfizer vaccine over concerns for myocarditis in response to guidelines from other countries. Young population who received Moderna for their first dose, may also mix vaccines and receive Pfizer for their second dose if they so choose.    The Japanese government is also preparing to begin third dose vaccination for healthcare workers at the end of November at the earliest.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211023071253/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/special/coronavirus/vaccine/japan_2021/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211017231523/https://www.fukushihoken.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/iryo/kansen/coronavaccine/daikibosesshu.html (Tokyo vaccination)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211023071407/https://osaka-mvc.com/ (Osaka vaccination)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211018003512/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211013/k10013306041000.html (Pfizer for youth)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211023071137/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211020/k10013315151000.html (Pfizer for youth)No change to previous policy. The wearing of facial masks in Japan is wide spread and continues to be recommended by the government. Masks should also be worn in schools by students and faculty members, and should only be removed when eating or partaking in physical activities.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211017023524/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211023070703/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/0000121431_00094.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211023070710/https://www.mext.go.jp/a_menu/coronavirus/mext_00020.htmlNo change to previous policy.  While infection rates continue to decrease in Tokyo, it was reported on Oct 20 that 60% of all cases in Tokyo are not traced and do not have known infection routes. Experts however urge the city to thoroughly investigate infection routes now that cases are low.  Early during the 5th wave, for many wards in Tokyo, close contact tracing has been overwhelmed and efforts have shifted to targeted/priority settings such as schools or elderly facilities and also have shifted focus in making sure those severely ill are properly traced.  For other prefectures, small-cluster contact tracing continues to be manually and comprehensively conducted, in addition to the utilization of the COVID-19 Contact-Confirming Application (COCOA).    https://web.archive.org/web/20211023070133/https://mainichi.jp/articles/20211022/k00/00m/040/091000c (current contact tracing efforts in Tokyo)  https://web.archive.org/web/20210823030440/https://www.yomiuri.co.jp/national/20210821-OYT1T50023/ (Tokyo & Saitama contact tracing overwhelmed)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211023070545/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/covid-19/kansenkakudaiboushi-iryouteikyou.htmlNo change to previous policy.  Rapid antigen tests are freely available to prevent potential outbreaks in schools. Rapid antigen tests are also being sold to the general public in pharmacies.    PCR tests are conducted at medical institutions designated by prefectures for returnee patients, outpatients, and when a doctors deems the testing be necessary. In some areas, with the cooperation of regional medical associations, "regional outpatient/examination center" have been set up to carry out intensive examinations and to determine testing. While symptomatic individuals are typically recommended, PCR testing can be made available at the discretion of certain institutions if a health centre or doctor determines an individual a close contact, even if asymptomatic. For PCR tests carried out at these institutions, patients will not be responsible for the cost of the tests. Patients however, are responsible for the initial consultation fee.    PCR tests, antigen tests, and antibody tests may be requested for asymptomatic individuals for the purposes of travel will however, be charged by laboratory facilities.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211008192307/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211005/k10013291931000.html (rapid antigen testing in schools)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211017225754/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211015/k10013309151000.html (rapid antigen tests in pharmacies)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211023065531/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/0000121431_00132.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211023065550/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/kenkou_iryou/dengue_fever_qa_00004.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211023065600/https://jp.usembassy.gov/services/pcr-testing-facilities-in-japan/Comprehensive public information about COVID-19 continues to be disseminated by the government.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211023065230/https://corona.go.jp/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211023065232/https://corona.go.jp/dashboard/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210814025731/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/special/coronavirus/data-widget/ (Dashboard properly loads in the non-archived version)  https://web.archive.org/web/20210731043406/https://www.stopcovid19.jp/ (Data properly loads in the non-archived version)No change to previous policy. New debt relief subsidy application deadlines for Nov 2021 to Dec 2021 have been set for February 28, 2022 (support document revised as of Oct 1).  The Japan Ministry of Health, Labour, and Welfare continues to provide debt relief: loans for small-lot emergency funds and comprehensive unemployment funds are provided at interest-free and payments may be deferred up to one year. Housing security loans are available for those at risk of losing housing: rent payments may be deferred up to 9-months with evidence of employment search. Property tax exemption may be available for applicants facing declining income or unemployment due to the pandemic. For single-parent households, family housing support loan of upto 40,000 yen for 12 months is available interest-free with the possibility of repayment exemption. Interviews for single-parent households will be conducted to understand their living conditions, motivation for employment, efforts to acquire qualifications, etc. A policy is also in place for the deferment for payments of national taxes.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211023065100/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/covid-19/kurashiyashigoto.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008205138/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/content/10900000/000622924.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20211023065132/https://corona.go.jp/actionNo change to previous policy. New unemployment subsidy application deadlines for Nov 2021 to Dec 2021 have been set for February 28, 2022 (support document revised as of Oct 1, p.34).  The Japan Ministry of Health, Labour, and Welfare continues to provide financial support in the forms of: employment subsidies to encourage business owners to maintain employees, leave of absence due to COVID-19 infection, living expenses for leave of absence or the unemployed, and special support for low-income child-rearing households for a maximum of 50,000 yen per child. Employment subsidies have a maximum of 15,000 yen per day per person.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211023065100/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/covid-19/kurashiyashigoto.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008205138/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/content/10900000/000622924.pdfNo change to previous policy. New unemployment subsidy application deadlines for Nov 2021 to Dec 2021 have been set for February 28, 2022 (support document revised as of Oct 1, p.34).  The Japan Ministry of Health, Labour, and Welfare continues to provide financial support in the forms of: employment subsidies to encourage business owners to maintain employees, leave of absence due to COVID-19 infection, living expenses for leave of absence or the unemployed, and special support for low-income child-rearing households for a maximum of 50,000 yen per child. Employment subsidies have a maximum of 15,000 yen per day per person.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211023065100/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/covid-19/kurashiyashigoto.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008205138/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/content/10900000/000622924.pdfBorder closure for entry into Japan continues to be in place. Travel for tourism and other short-term purposes remain restricted, while all Visa-free travel is suspended.  For travellers who are granted exceptional status for entry, various countries will have differing quarantine and testing requirements on arrival corresponding to country/region designation by variants of concern provided by the Japan Ministry of Foreign Affairs (latest list of specialty measures for regions is updated as of Sep 27).  To be eligible for a shortened quarantine period, Japan has so far designated only Pfizer, AstraZeneca, and Moderna as valid certificates of vaccination. All certificates must be issued by the public institution from government or country of origin, and must be written in either Japanese or English containing the following information: name, date of birth, vaccine name or manufacturer, vaccination date, dose. In addition, 14-days or more must have passed from the second dose date.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211023062720/https://jp.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008204749/https://www.mofa.go.jp/mofaj/files/100238774.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20211023062858/https://www.anzen.mofa.go.jp/info/pcwideareaspecificinfo_2021C129.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211023062737/https://www.anzen.mofa.go.jp/covid19/certificate_to_Japan.htmlThe government continues to encourage residents to practice precautions moving between prefectures, particularly to and from areas of high infection rates and particularly for those unvaccinated.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211023052152/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/The government continues to encourage people to avoid dense crowds and situations of high risk for infection, to refrain for unnecessary movement to areas with high infection rates and to cooperate with night-time business closures at 9:00PM (for prefectures still in precautionary periods).    https://web.archive.org/web/20211023052152/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/No change to previous policy. Businesses are asked to reduce the number of workers in the office by 70% through utilizing remote methods of work and to request employees finish work by 8:00PM.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211023052152/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003193347/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210929/k10013281591000.html (restrictions in Kanto region)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003193702/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210928/k10013281561000.html (restrictions in Tokyo)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211023063531/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211021/k10013316041000.html (lifting restrictions in Tokyo, Osaka, Kyoto, and Okinawa)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211023064057/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211020/k10013315581000.html (lifting restrictions in Saitama and Kanagawa)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003190552/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/_res/projects/default_project/_page_/001/015/636/20210928/torikumi.pdf (Tokyo until Oct 24)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211023061851/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211020/k10013314071000.html (Tokyo time restriction lifting Oct 25)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211023053608/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/_res/projects/default_project/_page_/001/020/469/20210928/20211021.pdf (Tokyo Oct 25-31)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008200105/https://www.pref.okinawa.lg.jp/site/chijiko/koho/corona/documents/1007taishohousin.pdf (Okinawa)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008200827/https://www.pref.okinawa.lg.jp/site/chijiko/koho/corona/documents/0928eigo.pdf (Okinawa)No change to previous policy as Japan lifts emergency and priority measures for all prefectures and continues undergoing a precautionary period for one month. From Oct 1 to Oct 24, Tokyo will undergo a period with various lighter restrictions. For Okinawa, the precautionary period is between Oct 1 to Oct 31.    Schools have all resumed in-person learning at full capacity due to measures being lifted. Schools are to continue undergoing stringent sanitation and infection prevention measures, restricting club activities with high risk of infection and suspension of all school excursions. Increased ventilation measures and distribution of antigen test kits will also continue to be conducted. Students with illness symptoms are not to attend schools. Individual schools may also have the jurisdiction to close due to in-school outbreaks on a school-by-school basis.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211023052152/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008192307/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211005/k10013291931000.html (school measures)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003190552/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/_res/projects/default_project/_page_/001/015/636/20210928/torikumi.pdf (Tokyo until Oct 24)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211023053608/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/_res/projects/default_project/_page_/001/020/469/20210928/20211021.pdf (Tokyo Oct 25-31)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008200105/https://www.pref.okinawa.lg.jp/site/chijiko/koho/corona/documents/1007taishohousin.pdf (Okinawa)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008200827/https://www.pref.okinawa.lg.jp/site/chijiko/koho/corona/documents/0928eigo.pdf (Okinawa)

No change to previous policy. Last report on provisional measures in nursing homes was published as of October 5, 2021.  The following preventative measures for the elderly continue to be conducted:  - Recommendations and communications for active/healthy living and staying indoors targeted towards senior citizens.  - Monthly evaluation of preventive and infection control measures within long-term care homes.  - Comprehensive information and training material for Long Term Care staff and ownership including donning/doffing of PPE, systematic area zoning within facilities, and procedures involving admissions, discharge, hygiene and garbage.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211102003529/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/hukushi_kaigo/kaigo_koureisha/index.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211102003536/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/hukushi_kaigo/kaigo_koureisha/taisakumatome_13635.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211102003632/http://kayoinoba.mhlw.go.jp/No change to previous policy.  Vaccination continues to be available and administered for all individuals age 12+ at the appropriate mass vaccination or muncipal vaccination sites.  Men in their teens and 20s to vaccinate may receive the Pfizer vaccine over concerns for myocarditis in response to guidelines from other countries. Young population who received Moderna for their first dose, may also mix vaccines and receive Pfizer for their second dose if they so choose.    Third dose inoculations are being prepared to be administered beginning December 2021. The priority for third dose vaccinations begin from the order of those who received their second doses 8 months prior (or more). The groups are as follows:  - Medical workers (first vaccinated in Feb) will be vaccinated from Dec.  - Elderly (first vaccinated in April) will be vaccinated from Jan 2022.  - Those with other priority inoculations including those with underlying illnesses.    In Osaka, Minami city, after calls for shortened business hours were lifted for restaurants on Oct 25, the city is testing out logistics for vaccination passports until Oct 29.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211102004111/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211101/k10013330171000.html (third dose)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211102004334/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211025/k10013321141000.html (vaccination passport in Minami)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211102003727/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/special/coronavirus/vaccine/japan_2021/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211102003759/https://www.fukushihoken.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/iryo/kansen/coronavaccine/daikibosesshu.html (Tokyo vaccination)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211102004155/https://osaka-mvc.com/ (Osaka vaccination)  No change to previous policy. The wearing of facial masks in Japan is wide spread and continues to be recommended by the government. Masks should also be worn in schools by students and faculty members, and should only be removed when eating or partaking in physical activities.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211023052152/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211102003434/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/0000121431_00094.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211102003432/https://www.mext.go.jp/a_menu/coronavirus/mext_00020.htmlNo change to previous policy.  While infection rates continue to decrease in Tokyo, it was reported on Oct 20 that 60% of all cases in Tokyo are not traced and do not have known infection routes. Experts however urge the city to thoroughly investigate infection routes now that cases are low.  Early during the 5th wave, for many wards in Tokyo, close contact tracing has been overwhelmed and efforts have shifted to targeted/priority settings such as schools or elderly facilities and also have shifted focus in making sure those severely ill are properly traced.  For other prefectures, small-cluster contact tracing continues to be manually and comprehensively conducted, in addition to the utilization of the COVID-19 Contact-Confirming Application (COCOA).    https://web.archive.org/web/20211023070133/https://mainichi.jp/articles/20211022/k00/00m/040/091000c (current contact tracing efforts in Tokyo)  https://web.archive.org/web/20210823030440/https://www.yomiuri.co.jp/national/20210821-OYT1T50023/ (Tokyo & Saitama contact tracing overwhelmed)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211102003031/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/covid-19/kansenkakudaiboushi-iryouteikyou.htmlNo change to previous policy.  Rapid antigen tests are freely available to prevent potential outbreaks in schools. Rapid antigen tests are also being sold to the general public in pharmacies.    PCR tests are conducted at medical institutions designated by prefectures for returnee patients, outpatients, and when a doctors deems the testing be necessary. In some areas, with the cooperation of regional medical associations, "regional outpatient/examination center" have been set up to carry out intensive examinations and to determine testing. While symptomatic individuals are typically recommended, PCR testing can be made available at the discretion of certain institutions if a health centre or doctor determines an individual a close contact, even if asymptomatic. For PCR tests carried out at these institutions, patients will not be responsible for the cost of the tests. Patients however, are responsible for the initial consultation fee.    PCR tests, antigen tests, and antibody tests may be requested for asymptomatic individuals for the purposes of travel will however, be charged by laboratory facilities.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211008192307/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211005/k10013291931000.html (rapid antigen testing in schools)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211017225754/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211015/k10013309151000.html (rapid antigen tests in pharmacies)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211102002805/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/0000121431_00132.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211102002808/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/kenkou_iryou/dengue_fever_qa_00004.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211102002840/https://jp.usembassy.gov/services/pcr-testing-facilities-in-japan/Comprehensive public information about COVID-19 continues to be disseminated by the government.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211102002603/https://corona.go.jp/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211102002727/https://corona.go.jp/dashboard/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210814025731/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/special/coronavirus/data-widget/ (Dashboard properly loads in the non-archived version)  https://web.archive.org/web/20210731043406/https://www.stopcovid19.jp/ (Data properly loads in the non-archived version)No change to previous policy. New debt relief subsidy application deadlines for Nov 2021 to Dec 2021 have been set for February 28, 2022 (support document revised as of Oct 20).  The Japan Ministry of Health, Labour, and Welfare continues to provide debt relief: loans for small-lot emergency funds and comprehensive unemployment funds are provided at interest-free and payments may be deferred up to one year. Housing security loans are available for those at risk of losing housing: rent payments may be deferred up to 9-months with evidence of employment search. Property tax exemption may be available for applicants facing declining income or unemployment due to the pandemic. For single-parent households, family housing support loan of upto 40,000 yen for 12 months is available interest-free with the possibility of repayment exemption. Interviews for single-parent households will be conducted to understand their living conditions, motivation for employment, efforts to acquire qualifications, etc. A policy is also in place for the deferment for payments of national taxes.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211102002210/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/covid-19/kurashiyashigoto.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211102002319/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/content/10900000/000622924.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20211102002518/https://corona.go.jp/actionNo change to previous policy. New unemployment subsidy application deadlines for Nov 2021 to Dec 2021 have been set for February 28, 2022 (support document revised as of Oct 20, p.24).  The Japan Ministry of Health, Labour, and Welfare continues to provide financial support in the forms of: employment subsidies to encourage business owners to maintain employees, leave of absence due to COVID-19 infection, living expenses for leave of absence or the unemployed, and special support for low-income child-rearing households for a maximum of 50,000 yen per child. Employment subsidies have a maximum of 15,000 yen per day per person.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211102002210/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/covid-19/kurashiyashigoto.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211102002319/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/content/10900000/000622924.pdfNo change to previous policy. New unemployment subsidy application deadlines for Nov 2021 to Dec 2021 have been set for February 28, 2022 (support document revised as of Oct 20, p.24).  The Japan Ministry of Health, Labour, and Welfare continues to provide financial support in the forms of: employment subsidies to encourage business owners to maintain employees, leave of absence due to COVID-19 infection, living expenses for leave of absence or the unemployed, and special support for low-income child-rearing households for a maximum of 50,000 yen per child. Employment subsidies have a maximum of 15,000 yen per day per person.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211102002210/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/covid-19/kurashiyashigoto.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211102002319/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/content/10900000/000622924.pdf

Border closure for entry into Japan continues to be in place. Travel for tourism and other short-term purposes remain restricted, while all Visa-free travel is suspended.  For travellers who are granted exceptional status for entry, various countries will have differing quarantine and testing requirements on arrival corresponding to country/region designation by variants of concern provided by the Japan Ministry of Foreign Affairs (latest list of specialty measures for regions is updated as of Sep 27).  To be eligible for a shortened quarantine period, Japan has so far designated only Pfizer, AstraZeneca, and Moderna as valid certificates of vaccination. All certificates must be issued by the public institution from government or country of origin, and must be written in either Japanese or English containing the following information: name, date of birth, vaccine name or manufacturer, vaccination date, dose. In addition, 14-days or more must have passed from the second dose date.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211102001901/https://jp.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008204749/https://www.mofa.go.jp/mofaj/files/100238774.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20211023062858/https://www.anzen.mofa.go.jp/info/pcwideareaspecificinfo_2021C129.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211102001917/https://www.anzen.mofa.go.jp/covid19/certificate_to_Japan.htmlThe government continues to encourage residents to practice precautions moving between prefectures, particularly to and from areas of high infection rates and particularly for those unvaccinated.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211101233011/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/The government continues to encourage people to avoid dense crowds and situations of high risk for infection, to refrain for unnecessary movement to areas with high infection rates and to cooperate with night-time business closures at 9:00PM (for prefectures still in precautionary periods).    https://web.archive.org/web/20211101233011/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/No change to previous policy. All public transportation continues to remain in operation.  Tokyo Metro is provided detailed information on congestion for each train line and train station at each hour.  Regular service continues on Japan Rail with heightened prevention measures including increase ventilation, physical distancing, disinfection, wearing of masks, and preventing passengers from rotating seats.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211102001615/https://www.tokyometro.jp/index.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211102001642/https://tmap-sid.tokyometro.jp/o/view/index.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211102001800/https://www.westjr.co.jp/info/corona_taisaku.htmlOn October 25, time restrictions on restaurants and alcohol service have been lifted in Tokyo, Osaka, Saitama, and Kanagawa.  On November 1, time restrictions on restaurants and alcohol service will be lifted in Okinawa.    During the precautionary period, all events are asked to be completed by 9:00PM. For events involving loud events, capacity is limited to 50% of the venue capacity or an upper limit of 10,000 people. For events with no loud voices, 100% of the venue capacity may be used but not exceed an upper limit of 5,000 people. In Tokyo and Okinawa, events are limited to 50% venue capacity and must not exceed 5,000 people.  Businesses in Okinawa are asked to reduce the number of workers in the office by 70% through utilizing remote methods of work and to request employees finish work by 8:00PM. PCR tests, antigen tests, and antibody tests may be requested for asymptomatic individuals for the purposes of travel will however, be charged by laboratory facilities.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211008192307/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211005/k10013291931000.html (rapid antigen testing in schools)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211017225754/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211015/k10013309151000.html (rapid antigen tests in pharmacies)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211106041522/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/0000121431_00132.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211106041527/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/kenkou_iryou/dengue_fever_qa_00004.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211106041550/https://jp.usembassy.gov/services/pcr-testing-facilities-in-japan/Comprehensive public information about COVID-19 continues to be disseminated by the government.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211106041421/https://corona.go.jp/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211106041440/https://corona.go.jp/dashboard/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210814025731/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/special/coronavirus/data-widget/ (Dashboard properly loads in the non-archived version)  https://web.archive.org/web/20210731043406/https://www.stopcovid19.jp/ (Data properly loads in the non-archived version)No change to previous policy. New debt relief subsidy application deadlines for Nov 2021 to Dec 2021 have been set for February 28, 2022 (support document revised as of Oct 20).  The Japan Ministry of Health, Labour, and Welfare continues to provide debt relief: loans for small-lot emergency funds and comprehensive unemployment funds are provided at interest-free and payments may be deferred up to one year. Housing security loans are available for those at risk of losing housing: rent payments may be deferred up to 9-months with evidence of employment search. Property tax exemption may be available for applicants facing declining income or unemployment due to the pandemic. For single-parent households, family housing support loan of upto 40,000 yen for 12 months is available interest-free with the possibility of repayment exemption. Interviews for single-parent households will be conducted to understand their living conditions, motivation for employment, efforts to acquire qualifications, etc. A policy is also in place for the deferment for payments of national taxes.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211106041348/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/covid-19/kurashiyashigoto.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211102002319/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/content/10900000/000622924.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20211106041332/https://corona.go.jp/actionNo change to previous policy. New unemployment subsidy application deadlines for Nov 2021 to Dec 2021 have been set for February 28, 2022 (support document revised as of Oct 20, p.24).  The Japan Ministry of Health, Labour, and Welfare continues to provide financial support in the forms of: employment subsidies to encourage business owners to maintain employees, leave of absence due to COVID-19 infection, living expenses for leave of absence or the unemployed, and special support for low-income child-rearing households for a maximum of 50,000 yen per child. Employment subsidies have a maximum of 15,000 yen per day per person.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211106041348/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/covid-19/kurashiyashigoto.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211102002319/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/content/10900000/000622924.pdfNo change to previous policy. The Japan Ministry of Health, Labour, and Welfare continues to provide financial support in the forms of: employment subsidies to encourage business owners to maintain employees, leave of absence due to COVID-19 infection, living expenses for leave of absence or the unemployed, and special support for low-income child-rearing households for a maximum of 50,000 yen per child. Employment subsidies have a maximum of 15,000 yen per day per person.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211106041348/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/covid-19/kurashiyashigoto.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211102002319/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/content/10900000/000622924.pdfThe government announces Japan will begin permitting entry of international students and shortening the quarantine period to 3-days for fully vaccinated individuals on business trips beginning November 8.    For all other non-residents, border closure for entry into Japan continues to be in place. Travel for tourism remain restricted, while all Visa-free travel is suspended. For travellers who are granted exceptional status for entry, various countries will have differing quarantine and testing requirements on arrival corresponding to country/region designation by variants of concern provided by the Japan Ministry of Foreign Affairs (latest list of specialty measures for regions is updated as of Nov 5).  To be eligible for a shortened quarantine period, Japan has so far designated only Pfizer, AstraZeneca, and Moderna as valid certificates of vaccination. All certificates must be issued by the public institution from government or country of origin, and must be written in either Japanese or English containing the following information: name, date of birth, vaccine name or manufacturer, vaccination date, dose. In addition, 14-days or more must have passed from the second dose date.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211106040544/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211105/k10013336361000.html (international students and business quarantine)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211102001901/https://jp.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211106041148/https://www.mofa.go.jp/mofaj/files/100256050.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20211106041201/https://www.anzen.mofa.go.jp/info/pcwideareaspecificinfo_2021C138.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211106041008/https://www.anzen.mofa.go.jp/covid19/certificate_to_Japan.htmlThe government continues to encourage residents to practice precautions moving between prefectures, particularly to and from areas of high infection rates and particularly for those unvaccinated.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211106032948/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/The government continues to encourage people to avoid dense crowds and situations of high risk for infection, to refrain for unnecessary movement to areas with high infection rates.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211106032948/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/No change to previous policy. For events with no loud cheering/shouting, a maximum of 5000 people are permitted to attend up to a venue's full capacity. Some visitation at elderly care homes continue to be restricted. The government is considering the resumption of visitations for fully vaccinated visitors.    Last report on provisional measures in nursing homes was published as of November 4, 2021.  The following preventative measures for the elderly also continue to be conducted:  - Recommendations and communications for active/healthy living and staying indoors targeted towards senior citizens.  - Monthly evaluation of preventive and infection control measures within long-term care homes.  - Supply infection prevention items such as masks, other PPE, and disinfectants,  - Comprehensive information and training material for Long Term Care staff and ownership including donning/doffing of PPE, systematic area zoning within facilities, and procedures involving admissions, discharge, hygiene and garbage.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211112054033/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211110/k10013341201000.html (visitations for fully vaccinated visitors)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211112054232/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/hukushi_kaigo/kaigo_koureisha/index.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211112054206/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/hukushi_kaigo/kaigo_koureisha/taisakumatome_13635.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211112054300/http://kayoinoba.mhlw.go.jp/No change to previous policy. The wearing of facial masks in Japan is wide spread and continues to be recommended by the government. Masks should also be worn in schools by students and faculty members, and should only be removed when eating or partaking in physical activities.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211112041455/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211112053527/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/0000121431_00094.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211112053535/https://www.mext.go.jp/a_menu/coronavirus/mext_00020.html60% of all cases in Tokyo are not traced and do not have known infection routes. There is no evidence that contact tracing in Tokyo has improved.    Early during the 5th wave, for many wards in Tokyo, close contact tracing has been overwhelmed and efforts have shifted to targeted/priority settings such as schools or elderly facilities and also have shifted focus in making sure those severely ill are properly traced.  For other prefectures, small-cluster contact tracing continues to be manually and comprehensively conducted, in addition to the utilization of the COVID-19 Contact-Confirming Application (COCOA).    https://web.archive.org/web/20211023070133/https://mainichi.jp/articles/20211022/k00/00m/040/091000c (current contact tracing efforts in Tokyo)  https://web.archive.org/web/20210823030440/https://www.yomiuri.co.jp/national/20210821-OYT1T50023/ (Tokyo & Saitama contact tracing overwhelmed)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211106041736/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/covid-19/kansenkakudaiboushi-iryouteikyou.htmlIn preparation of wave 6 of infections, the government is considering offering free PCR and rapid antigen testing to all individuals including those who are asymptomatic. However, as of now, only symptomatic and those in close contact with a positive case are eligible for free testing.    PCR tests are conducted at medical institutions designated by prefectures for returnee patients, outpatients, and when a doctors deems the testing be necessary. In some areas, with the cooperation of regional medical associations, "regional outpatient/examination center" have been set up to carry out intensive examinations and to determine testing. While symptomatic individuals are typically recommended, PCR testing can be made available at the discretion of certain institutions if a health centre or doctor determines an individual a close contact, even if asymptomatic. For PCR tests carried out at these institutions, patients will not be responsible for the cost of the tests. Patients however, are responsible for the initial consultation fee.    PCR tests, antigen tests, and antibody tests may be requested for asymptomatic individuals for the purposes of travel will however, be charged by laboratory facilities.  Rapid antigen tests are also freely available to prevent potential outbreaks in schools. Rapid antigen tests are also being sold to the general public in pharmacies.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211112050813/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211108/k10013339271000.html (considerations for asymptomatic testing)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008192307/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211005/k10013291931000.html (rapid antigen testing in schools)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211017225754/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211015/k10013309151000.html (rapid antigen tests in pharmacies)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211106041522/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/0000121431_00132.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211112050713/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/kenkou_iryou/dengue_fever_qa_00004.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211112050801/https://jp.usembassy.gov/services/pcr-testing-facilities-in-japan/Comprehensive public information about COVID-19 continues to be disseminated by the government.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211106041421/https://corona.go.jp/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211106041440/https://corona.go.jp/dashboard/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210814025731/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/special/coronavirus/data-widget/ (Dashboard properly loads in the non-archived version)  https://web.archive.org/web/20210731043406/https://www.stopcovid19.jp/ (Data properly loads in the non-archived version)No change to previous policy. On November 8, Japan has shortenedthe quarantine period to 3-days for all incoming fully vaccinated travellers. International students on scolarships with Japanese universities are also permitted to enter Japan. However, The government continues to limit the number of people allowed to enter the country per day to 3,500, including Japanese citizens.    For all other non-residents, border closure for entry into Japan continues to be in place. Travel for tourism remain restricted, while all Visa-free travel is suspended. For travellers who are granted exceptional status for entry, various countries will have differing quarantine and testing requirements on arrival corresponding to country/region designation by variants of concern provided by the Japan Ministry of Foreign Affairs (latest list of specialty measures for regions is updated as of Nov 5).  To be eligible for a shortened quarantine period, Japan has so far designated only Pfizer, AstraZeneca, and Moderna as valid certificates of vaccination. All certificates must be issued by the public institution from government or country of origin, and must be written in either Japanese or English containing the following information: name, date of birth, vaccine name or manufacturer, vaccination date, dose. In addition, 14-days or more must have passed from the second dose date.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211112044348/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211108/k10013338331000.html (international students and business quarantine)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211112044708/https://jp.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211106041148/https://www.mofa.go.jp/mofaj/files/100256050.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20211112044919/https://www.anzen.mofa.go.jp/info/pcwideareaspecificinfo_2021C138.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211112044943/https://www.anzen.mofa.go.jp/covid19/certificate_to_Japan.html

On November 11, the government authorizes the Pfizer vaccine to be used for third dose vaccination set to begin in December.  Third dose inoculations are being prepared to be administered beginning December 2021. The priority for third dose vaccinations begin from the order of those who received their second doses 8 months prior (or more). The groups are as follows:  - Medical workers (first vaccinated in Feb) will be vaccinated from Dec.  - Elderly (first vaccinated in April) will be vaccinated from Jan 2022.  - Those with other priority inoculations including those with underlying illnesses.    Vaccination continues to be available and administered for all individuals age 12+ at the appropriate mass vaccination or muncipal vaccination sites.  Men in their teens and 20s to vaccinate may receive the Pfizer vaccine over concerns for myocarditis in response to guidelines from other countries. Young population who received Moderna for their first dose, may also mix vaccines and receive Pfizer for their second dose if they so choose.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211112054416/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211111/k10013343621000.html (Pfizer third dose)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211102004111/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211101/k10013330171000.html (third dose)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211106042219/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/special/coronavirus/vaccine/japan_2021/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211112054622/https://www.fukushihoken.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/iryo/kansen/coronavaccine/daikibosesshu.html (Tokyo vaccination)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211112054719/https://osaka-mvc.com/ (Osaka vaccination)

On November 12, the Japanese government announces change in testing policy. As a pre-emptive measure in preparations for countering against a sixth wave of infection, free PCR and antigen testing have become available for asymptomatic individuals.    Despite the announcement we cannot find any firm dates when the policy comes in to force. Should dates become clearer at a leter date we will adjust the policy accordingly.    Kishida announced Friday that, while new cases are rising, individuals who can’t be vaccinated for health reasons and who don’t have symptoms but are concerned they have been infected can receive a PCR or antigen test before taking part in certain economic or social activities.    The plan is part of a greater effort to prepare the country for a sixth wave of the pandemic — and whatever comes afterwards — by bolstering hospitals, procuring more medical staff, expanding its vaccine campaign, administering booster shots and advancing the treatment of those with COVID-19.    “While new cases have declined substantially, it’s important to acknowledge the strong possibility that the virus will return and to prepare accordingly,” Kishida said Friday.    It’s not exactly clear who will be eligible and under what circumstances, but Kishida said Friday that the decision will be left to local governments, who have been directed to execute the plan at the latest by the end of March 2022.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211114022125/https://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2021/11/12/national/covid19-policies-free-testing/    https://web.archive.org/web/20211119050612/https://www.yomiuri.co.jp/politics/20211107-OYT1T50148/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211119050745/https://toyokeizai.net/articles/-/469112  https://web.archive.org/web/20211119042821/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211115/k10013349111000.html (logistics for free asymptomatic testing)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211112050813/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211108/k10013339271000.html (considerations for asymptomatic testing)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211119050557/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/0000121431_00132.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211119045214/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/kenkou_iryou/dengue_fever_qa_00004.html

No change to previous policy.  Some visitation at elderly care homes continue to be restricted. The government is considering the resumption of visitations for fully vaccinated visitors.    Last report on provisional measures in nursing homes was published as of November 8, 2021.  The following preventative measures for the elderly also continue to be conducted:  - Recommendations and communications for active/healthy living and staying indoors targeted towards senior citizens.  - Monthly evaluation of preventive and infection control measures within long-term care homes.  - Supply infection prevention items such as masks, other PPE, and disinfectants,  - Comprehensive information and training material for Long Term Care staff and ownership including donning/doffing of PPE, systematic area zoning within facilities, and procedures involving admissions, discharge, hygiene and garbage.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211112054033/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211110/k10013341201000.html (visitations for fully vaccinated visitors)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211119044234/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/hukushi_kaigo/kaigo_koureisha/index.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211119044210/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/hukushi_kaigo/kaigo_koureisha/taisakumatome_13635.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211112054300/http://kayoinoba.mhlw.go.jp/The government announces vaccination for 5-11 year olds are currently under the review process and is expected to begin February 2022 at the earliest.    Third dose inoculations are being prepared to be administered beginning December 2021. The priority for third dose vaccinations begin from the order of those who received their second doses 8 months prior (or more). The groups are as follows:  - Medical workers (first vaccinated in Feb) will be vaccinated from Dec.  - Elderly (first vaccinated in April) will be vaccinated from Jan 2022.  - Those with other priority inoculations including those with underlying illnesses.    Vaccination continues to be available and administered for all individuals age 12+ at the appropriate mass vaccination or muncipal vaccination sites.  Men in their teens and 20s to vaccinate may receive the Pfizer vaccine over concerns for myocarditis in response to guidelines from other countries. Young population who received Moderna for their first dose, may also mix vaccines and receive Pfizer for their second dose if they so choose. There are also no-reservation vaccination clinics available for non-Japanese speakers with clinic attendees who are able to communicate in multiple foreign languages.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211119044541/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211117/k10013351001000.html (5-11 year olds)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211119044634/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211115/k10013348971000.html (non-Japanese speakers)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211102004111/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211101/k10013330171000.html (third dose)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211106042219/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/special/coronavirus/vaccine/japan_2021/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211112054622/https://www.fukushihoken.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/iryo/kansen/coronavaccine/daikibosesshu.html (Tokyo vaccination)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211112054719/https://osaka-mvc.com/ (Osaka vaccination)No change to previous policy. The wearing of facial masks in Japan is wide spread and continues to be recommended by the government. Masks should also be worn in schools by students and faculty members, and should only be removed when eating or partaking in physical activities.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211112041455/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211119044032/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/0000121431_00094.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211119043955/https://www.mext.go.jp/a_menu/coronavirus/mext_00020.html60% of all cases in Tokyo are not traced and do not have known infection routes. There is no evidence that contact tracing in Tokyo has improved.  In Osaka, in preparations for a sixth wave, contact tracing has been outsourced to private companies to help with the efforts reaching out to potential close contacts.    Early during the 5th wave, for many wards in Tokyo, close contact tracing has been overwhelmed and efforts have shifted to targeted/priority settings such as schools or elderly facilities and also have shifted focus in making sure those severely ill are properly traced.  For other prefectures, small-cluster contact tracing continues to be manually and comprehensively conducted, in addition to the utilization of the COVID-19 Contact-Confirming Application (COCOA).    https://web.archive.org/web/20211119043622/https://www.yomiuri.co.jp/local/kansai/news/20211118-OYO1T50021/ (contat tracing efforts in Osaka)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211023070133/https://mainichi.jp/articles/20211022/k00/00m/040/091000c (current contact tracing efforts in Tokyo)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211106041736/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/covid-19/kansenkakudaiboushi-iryouteikyou.htmlComprehensive public information about COVID-19 continues to be disseminated by the government.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211119042711/https://corona.go.jp/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211106041440/https://corona.go.jp/dashboard/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210814025731/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/special/coronavirus/data-widget/ (Dashboard properly loads in the non-archived version)  https://web.archive.org/web/20210731043406/https://www.stopcovid19.jp/ (Data properly loads in the non-archived version)No change to previous policy. New debt relief subsidy application deadlines for Nov 2021 to Dec 2021 have been set for February 28, 2022 (support document revised as of Oct 20).  The Japan Ministry of Health, Labour, and Welfare continues to provide debt relief: loans for small-lot emergency funds and comprehensive unemployment funds are provided at interest-free and payments may be deferred up to one year. Housing security loans are available for those at risk of losing housing: rent payments may be deferred up to 9-months with evidence of employment search. Property tax exemption may be available for applicants facing declining income or unemployment due to the pandemic. For single-parent households, family housing support loan of upto 40,000 yen for 12 months is available interest-free with the possibility of repayment exemption. Interviews for single-parent households will be conducted to understand their living conditions, motivation for employment, efforts to acquire qualifications, etc. A policy is also in place for the deferment for payments of national taxes.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211119042136/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/covid-19/kurashiyashigoto.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211102002319/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/content/10900000/000622924.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20211119042254/https://corona.go.jp/actionNo change to previous policy. New unemployment subsidy application deadlines for Nov 2021 to Dec 2021 have been set for February 28, 2022 (support document revised as of Oct 20, p.24).  The Japan Ministry of Health, Labour, and Welfare continues to provide financial support in the forms of: employment subsidies to encourage business owners to maintain employees, leave of absence due to COVID-19 infection, living expenses for leave of absence or the unemployed, and special support for low-income child-rearing households for a maximum of 50,000 yen per child. Employment subsidies have a maximum of 15,000 yen per day per person.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211119042136/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/covid-19/kurashiyashigoto.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211102002319/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/content/10900000/000622924.pdfNo change to previous policy. Employment subsidies have a maximum of 15,000 yen per day per person.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211119042136/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/covid-19/kurashiyashigoto.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211102002319/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/content/10900000/000622924.pdfNo change to previous policy. All public transportation continues to remain in operation.  Tokyo Metro is provided detailed information on congestion for each train line and train station at each hour.  Regular service continues on Japan Rail with heightened prevention measures including increase ventilation, physical distancing, disinfection, wearing of masks, and preventing passengers from rotating seats.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211119035030/https://www.tokyometro.jp/index.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211119035045/https://tmap-sid.tokyometro.jp/o/view/index.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211112043820/https://www.westjr.co.jp/info/corona_taisaku.htmlNo change to previous policy. All public events have resumed.  For events with no loud cheering/shouting, a maximum of 5000 people are permitted to attend up to a venue's full capacity.  For events with loud cheering/shouting, gatherings may occur up to half a venue's capacity.    For events that require attendees to move across the country, the government is encouraging those events to be cancelled. However, if necessary, when holding an event that involves nationwide movement or an event with more than 1,000 participants, event holders may also consult directly with city or prefectural authorities to safely hold the event.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211119021214/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008192307/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211005/k10013291931000.html (school measures)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211112041621/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/1009757/1020465.html (Tokyo Oct 31-Nov 30)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211112041636/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/1009757/1020468.html (Tokyo FAQ)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211106034542/https://www.pref.okinawa.lg.jp/site/chijiko/koho/corona/documents/1028taishohoshin_1.pdf (Okinawa Nov 1-30)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211106034546/https://www.pref.okinawa.lg.jp/site/chijiko/koho/corona/documents/1028eigo.pdf (Okinawa Nov 1-30)No change to previous policy.  All public events have resumed. The government has provided detailed guidelines on infection control measures to reduce risk of outbreaks, including providing separate entrances and exits, and limiting personnel depending on venue capacity.    For events that require attendees to move across the country, the government is encouraging those events to be cancelled. However, if necessary, when holding an event that involves nationwide movement or an event with more than 1,000 participants, event holders may also consult directly with city or prefectural authorities to safely hold the event.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211119021214/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008192307/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211005/k10013291931000.html (school measures)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211112041621/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/1009757/1020465.html (Tokyo Oct 31-Nov 30)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211112041636/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/1009757/1020468.html (Tokyo FAQ)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211106034542/https://www.pref.okinawa.lg.jp/site/chijiko/koho/corona/documents/1028taishohoshin_1.pdf (Okinawa Nov 1-30)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211106034546/https://www.pref.okinawa.lg.jp/site/chijiko/koho/corona/documents/1028eigo.pdf (Okinawa Nov 1-30)No change to previous policy.  Time restrictions on restaurants and alcohol service have been lifted in all prefectures.  Infection control continue to be recommended for all businesses, however no closures are in place for any industry. Businesses are also recommended to continue working from home (telework) if able, expand staggered commuting, and take other measures to prevent denseness during commuting and work.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211119021214/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008192307/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211005/k10013291931000.html (school measures)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211112041621/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/1009757/1020465.html (Tokyo Oct 31-Nov 30)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211112041636/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/1009757/1020468.html (Tokyo FAQ)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211106034542/https://www.pref.okinawa.lg.jp/site/chijiko/koho/corona/documents/1028taishohoshin_1.pdf (Okinawa Nov 1-30)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211106034546/https://www.pref.okinawa.lg.jp/site/chijiko/koho/corona/documents/1028eigo.pdf (Okinawa Nov 1-30)No change to previous policy.  As all precautionary measures have now been lifted in all prefectures, schools have all resumed in-person learning at full capacity due to measures being lifted. Schools are to continue undergoing stringent sanitation and infection prevention measures, increased ventilation measures, and distribute rapid antigen test kits. Students with illness symptoms are not to attend schools. Individual schools may also have the jurisdiction to close due to in-school outbreaks on a school-by-school basis.  Schools have also resumed all club activities, events, and excursions; however strict infection control measures must be followed.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211119021214/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008192307/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211005/k10013291931000.html (school measures)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211112041621/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/1009757/1020465.html (Tokyo Oct 31-Nov 30)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211112041636/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/1009757/1020468.html (Tokyo FAQ)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211106034542/https://www.pref.okinawa.lg.jp/site/chijiko/koho/corona/documents/1028taishohoshin_1.pdf (Okinawa Nov 1-30)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211106034546/https://www.pref.okinawa.lg.jp/site/chijiko/koho/corona/documents/1028eigo.pdf (Okinawa Nov 1-30)

Beginning November 24, the government allows visitations at long-term care homes restricted to visitors who have been fully vaccinated with two doses of the COVID-19 vaccination or have had a negative PCR test prior to the visitation.    Last report on provisional measures in nursing homes was published as of November 8, 2021.  The following preventative measures for the elderly also continue to be conducted:  - Recommendations and communications for active/healthy living and staying indoors targeted towards senior citizens.  - Monthly evaluation of preventive and infection control measures within long-term care homes.  - Supply infection prevention items such as masks, other PPE, and disinfectants,  - Comprehensive information and training material for Long Term Care staff and ownership including donning/doffing of PPE, systematic area zoning within facilities, and procedures involving admissions, discharge, hygiene and garbage.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211130023257/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211125/k10013360411000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211119044234/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/hukushi_kaigo/kaigo_koureisha/index.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211130023010/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/hukushi_kaigo/kaigo_koureisha/taisakumatome_13635.htmlIn preparations for to begin third dose vaccinations on December 1, 2021, governments of each regional local have been sending out vaccination invitations to medical professionals across the country. Previously the government had announced that only those who had received their second dose 8-months prior qualify for third doses at this time. However, they have since revised this timeline to 6-months for targeted personnel that either work or reside in places identified as high transmission risk such as long term care homes or medical institutions.    As of November 22, 2021, 76.2% of all of Japan's population has received 2-doses.  Vaccination continues to be available and administered for all individuals age 12+ at the appropriate mass vaccination or muncipal vaccination sites.  Men in their teens and 20s to vaccinate may receive the Pfizer vaccine over concerns for myocarditis in response to guidelines from other countries. Young population who received Moderna for their first dose, may also mix vaccines and receive Pfizer for their second dose if they so choose.
