Masks should also be worn in schools by students and faculty members, and should only be removed when eating or partaking in physical activities.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211130005213/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211130022837/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/0000121431_00094.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211130022914/https://www.mext.go.jp/a_menu/coronavirus/mext_00020.htmlThere is no evidence that contact tracing in Tokyo has improved. 60% of all cases in Tokyo are not traced and do not have known infection routes.   In Osaka, in preparations for a sixth wave, contact tracing has been outsourced to private companies to help with the efforts reaching out to potential close contacts.    Early during the 5th wave, for many wards in Tokyo, close contact tracing were overwhelmed and efforts have shifted to targeted/priority settings such as schools or elderly facilities and also have shifted focus in making sure those severely ill are properly traced.  For other prefectures, small-cluster contact tracing continues to be manually and comprehensively conducted, in addition to the utilization of the COVID-19 Contact-Confirming Application (COCOA).    https://web.archive.org/web/20211119043622/https://www.yomiuri.co.jp/local/kansai/news/20211118-OYO1T50021/ (contat tracing efforts in Osaka)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211023070133/https://mainichi.jp/articles/20211022/k00/00m/040/091000c (current contact tracing efforts in Tokyo)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211130022723/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/covid-19/kansenkakudaiboushi-iryouteikyou.htmlWhile the federal government in Japan is calling on individual locals to prepare for the administration of free PCR test, prefectures have by the end of March 2022 to fully implement the policy.  In Tokyo, the government has announced free PCR testing will become available for those who cannot be vaccinated by mid-December in preparations for the sixth wave of infections.  In Mie, free PCR testing for asymptomatic individuals who live, work, or attend school in the prefecture are eligible from October 11, 2021 to December 10, 2021.  In Tokushima, free PCR testing for asymptomatic individuals is in place but only for those returning into Tokushima prefecture by December 31, 2021.  In Kagawa, the government has announced they will provide free PCR testing for asymptomatic returning individuals into Kagawa from December 6.    PCR tests are conducted at medical institutions designated by prefectures for returnee patients, outpatients, and when a doctors deems the testing be necessary. In some areas, with the cooperation of regional medical associations, "regional outpatient/examination center" have been set up to carry out intensive examinations and to determine testing. While symptomatic individuals are typically recommended, PCR testing can be made available at the discretion of certain institutions if a health centre or doctor determines an individual a close contact, even if asymptomatic. For PCR tests carried out at these institutions, patients will not be responsible for the cost of the tests. New debt relief subsidy application deadlines for Nov 2021 to Dec 2021 have been set for February 28, 2022 (support document revised as of Nov 26).  The Japan Ministry of Health, Labour, and Welfare continues to provide debt relief: loans for small-lot emergency funds and comprehensive unemployment funds are provided at interest-free and payments may be deferred up to one year. Housing security loans are available for those at risk of losing housing: rent payments may be deferred up to 9-months with evidence of employment search. Property tax exemption may be available for applicants facing declining income or unemployment due to the pandemic. For single-parent households, family housing support loan of upto 40,000 yen for 12 months is available interest-free for a one-time redemption if the parent continues to work for a year. Interviews for single-parent households will be conducted to understand their living conditions, motivation for employment, efforts to acquire qualifications, etc. A policy is also in place for the deferment for payments of national taxes.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211130014630/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/covid-19/kurashiyashigoto.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211130014824/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/content/10900000/000622924.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20211130014656/https://corona.go.jp/actionNo change to previous policy. For events with loud cheering/shouting, gatherings may occur up to half a venue's capacity.    The following approval policy will not be required going forward from December 1: For events in Tokyo that require attendees to move across the country, the Tokyo government is encouraging those events to be cancelled. Beginning November 24 2021, the government begins allowing visitations at long-term care homes restricted to visitors who have been fully vaccinated with two doses of the COVID-19 vaccination or have had a negative PCR test prior to the visitation.    Last report on provisional measures in nursing homes was published as of December 27, 2021.  The following preventative measures for the elderly also continue to be conducted:  - Recommendations and communications for active/healthy living and staying indoors targeted towards senior citizens.  - Monthly evaluation of preventive and infection control measures within long-term care homes.  - Supply infection prevention items such as masks, other PPE, and disinfectants,  - Comprehensive information and training material for Long Term Care staff and ownership including donning/doffing of PPE, systematic area zoning within facilities, and procedures involving admissions, discharge, hygiene and garbage.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211112054033/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211110/k10013341201000.html (visitations for fully vaccinated visitors)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211130023257/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211125/k10013360411000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220123222226/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/hukushi_kaigo/kaigo_koureisha/index.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220123222227/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/hukushi_kaigo/kaigo_koureisha/taisakumatome_13635.html

On December 1, third doses begin being administered to healthcare workers. The government is targeting a total of 1.04 million medical staff in December.  In January, 2 million medical workers, 610,000 elderly people aged 65 and over, and 420,000 people aged 64 and under who received the second vaccination early will become eligible.  In Feburary, 1.83 million medical workers and 11.6 million elderly people, 730,000 under 64 years old will be eligible.  In March, 890,000 medical workers, 16.24 million elderly people, 64 years old or younger In addition to 4.35 million people, 1.68 million people who are "work-related inoculations" conducted at companies and universities are also eligible.  In April, 3.13 million elderly people, 11.94 million people under 64 years old, 5 million occupational inoculations will be eligible.  In May, 580,000 elderly people, 14.62 million people under 64 years old, 1.55 million occupational inoculations will be eligible.  In June, 350,000 elderly people, 12.73 million under 64 years old, and 2.48 million occupational inoculations will be eligible and continue until September 2022.    Mass vaccination sites operated by the Self-Defence Forces in Tokyo and Osaka have now closed. All vaccination sites continue and be operated by prefectural and municipal governments.    Children age 5-11 in Japan will likely begin vaccinations in February 2022.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211203031729/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211201/k10013369451000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211203032146/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211201/k10013369651000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211203033017/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211130/k10013368491000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211202173408/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211202/k10013370651000.htmlOn December 1st, the Ministry of Land, Infrastructure, Transport and Tourism in Japan will be suspending new bookings on all international flights coming into Japan for the entire month of December. On December 3, the Tokyo Metropolitan Governmnet held an emergency meeting in preparatons for the Omicon variant. The government announces contact tracing personnel will increase from what is now currently 1750 to approximately 3400 workers in order to comprehensively trace close contacts within Tokyo.    Other prefectures such as Osaka, Hyogo, and Kyoto have also been expanding contact tracing support staff and additional training in preparations for a sixth wave.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211213155146/https://www.nikkei.com/article/DGXZQOCC0375T0T01C21A2000000/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211213160731/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211207/k10013379001000.html (contact tracing efforts in Tokyo)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211213160820/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211210/k10013383221000.html (contact tracing efforts in Tokyo)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211213155717/https://www.yomiuri.co.jp/local/kansai/news/20211118-OYO1T50021/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211213155749/https://www.mbs.jp/news/kansainews/20211209/GE00041439.shtml  https://web.archive.org/web/20211213160834/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/covid-19/kansenkakudaiboushi-iryouteikyou.html

No change to previous policy. On December 1, third doses begin being administered to healthcare workers. The government is targeting a total of 1.04 million medical staff in December.   As of December 12, the Japanese government reports third doses have been administered 52,737 times nationwide to frontline healthcare workers.    Municipal and prefectural inoculation centres continue to be available for all those 12+ who wish to receive their first or second dose of the vaccine.  Children age 5-11 in Japan will likely begin vaccinations in February 2022 once approval has been completed.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211213154324/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/special/coronavirus/vaccine/japan_2021/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211203031729/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211201/k10013369451000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211203032146/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211201/k10013369651000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211202173408/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211202/k10013370651000.htmlNo change to previous policy. The wearing of facial masks in Japan is wide spread and continues to be recommended by the government. Masks should also be worn in schools by students and faculty members, and should only be removed when eating or partaking in physical activities.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211213150916/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211213153214/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/0000121431_00094.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211213153239/https://www.mext.go.jp/a_menu/coronavirus/mext_00020.htmlThe Ministry of Health, Labor and Welfare has announced they will gradually be reducing the cost of PCR testing for those asymptomatic, and these tests will be partially covered by the public medical insurance.   The current 18,000 yen will be reduced to 13,500 yen from December 31, and 7,000 yen from April 2022. Those symptomatic who have symptoms such as fever or have been identified as a close contact do not have to pay for PCR testing.  The government is also considering allowing rapid antigen tests to be purchased online by companies and restaurants to expand widescale testing.    Free PCR testing in Kagawa to all those asymptomatic and returning to the region will operate from December 6 to December 22 2021.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211213161801/https://www.nikkei.com/article/DGXZQOUA0893N0Y1A201C2000000/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211213160925/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211207/k10013377321000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211213161811/https://www.city.mitoyo.lg.jp/kakuka/kenkofukushi/kenko/8/corona/9059.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211213161939/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/0000121431_00132.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211213162005/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/kenkou_iryou/dengue_fever_qa_00004.htmlComprehensive public information about COVID-19 continues to be disseminated by the government.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211213153018/https://corona.go.jp/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211213153039/https://corona.go.jp/dashboard/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210814025731/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/special/coronavirus/data-widget/ (Dashboard properly loads in the non-archived version)  https://web.archive.org/web/20210731043406/https://www.stopcovid19.jp/ (Data properly loads in the non-archived version)No change to previous policy. New debt relief subsidy application deadlines for Nov 2021 to Dec 2021 have been set for February 28, 2022 (support document revised as of Nov 26).  The Japan Ministry of Health, Labour, and Welfare continues to provide debt relief: loans for small-lot emergency funds and comprehensive unemployment funds are provided at interest-free and payments may be deferred up to one year. Housing security loans are available for those at risk of losing housing: rent payments may be deferred up to 9-months with evidence of employment search. Property tax exemption may be available for applicants facing declining income or unemployment due to the pandemic. For single-parent households, family housing support loan of upto 40,000 yen for 12 months is available interest-free for a one-time redemption if the parent continues to work for a year. Interviews for single-parent households will be conducted to understand their living conditions, motivation for employment, efforts to acquire qualifications, etc. A policy is also in place for the deferment for payments of national taxes.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211213152610/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/covid-19/kurashiyashigoto.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211130014824/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/content/10900000/000622924.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20211213152935/https://corona.go.jp/actionNo change to previous policy. New unemployment subsidy application deadlines for Nov 2021 to Dec 2021 have been set for February 28, 2022 (support document revised as of Nov 26).  The Japan Ministry of Health, Labour, and Welfare continues to provide financial support in the forms of: employment subsidies to encourage business owners to maintain employees, leave of absence due to COVID-19 infection, living expenses for leave of absence or the unemployed, and special support for low-income child-rearing households for a maximum of 50,000 yen per child. Employment subsidies have a maximum of 15,000 yen per day per person.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211213152610/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/covid-19/kurashiyashigoto.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211130014824/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/content/10900000/000622924.pdfNo change to previous policy. New unemployment subsidy application deadlines for Nov 2021 to Dec 2021 have been set for February 28, 2022 (support document revised as of Nov 26).  The Japan Ministry of Health, Labour, and Welfare continues to provide financial support in the forms of: employment subsidies to encourage business owners to maintain employees, leave of absence due to COVID-19 infection, living expenses for leave of absence or the unemployed, and special support for low-income child-rearing households for a maximum of 50,000 yen per child. Employment subsidies have a maximum of 15,000 yen per day per person.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211213152610/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/covid-19/kurashiyashigoto.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211130014824/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/content/10900000/000622924.pdfThe government has lifted ban from additional Japanese nationals returning into Japan and on December 4 2021, Japanese airlines have resumed allowed Japanese nationals to book incoming flights up to a maximum of 3,500 people per day.  For all other travellers, Japan continues to prohibit entry for non-Visa travel and limited Visas are being processed.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211213152325/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211203/k10013374241000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211213152359/https://jp.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211213152524/https://www.anzen.mofa.go.jp/info/pcwideareaspecificinfo_2021C157.htmlThe government continues to encourage residents to practice precautions moving between prefectures, particularly to and from areas of high infection rates and particularly for those unvaccinated.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211213150916/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/The government continues to encourage people to avoid dense crowds and situations of high risk for infection, to refrain for unnecessary movement to areas with high infection rates.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211213150916/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/No change to previous policy. All public transportation continues to remain in operation.  Tokyo Metro is provided detailed information on congestion for each train line and train station at each hour.  Regular service continues on Japan Rail with heightened prevention measures including increase ventilation, physical distancing, disinfection, wearing of masks, and preventing passengers from rotating seats.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211213151313/https://www.tokyometro.jp/index.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211213151339/https://tmap-sid.tokyometro.jp/o/view/index.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211213151458/https://www.westjr.co.jp/info/corona_taisaku.htmlNo change to previous policy.  For events with no loud cheering/shouting, a maximum of 5000 people are permitted to attend up to a venue's full capacity. All public events have resumed. The government has provided detailed guidelines on infection control measures to reduce risk of outbreaks, including providing separate entrances and exits, and limiting personnel depending on venue capacity.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211213150916/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008192307/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211005/k10013291931000.html (school measures)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211130012156/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/1009757/1020631.html (Tokyo basic measures from Dec 1)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211130012221/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/1009757/1020626.html (Tokyo basic gathering measures from Dec 1)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211130012732/https://www.pref.okinawa.lg.jp/site/chijiko/koho/corona/documents/1125hoshin_1.pdf (Okinawa basic measures from Nov 25)No change to previous policy.  Time restrictions on restaurants and alcohol service have been lifted in all prefectures.  Infection control continue to be recommended for all businesses, however no closures are in place for any industry. Businesses are also recommended to continue working from home (telework) if able, expand staggered commuting, and take other measures to prevent denseness during commuting and work.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211213150916/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008192307/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211005/k10013291931000.html (school measures)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211130012156/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/1009757/1020631.html (Tokyo basic measures from Dec 1)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211130012221/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/1009757/1020626.html (Tokyo basic gathering measures from Dec 1)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211130012732/https://www.pref.okinawa.lg.jp/site/chijiko/koho/corona/documents/1125hoshin_1.pdf (Okinawa basic measures from Nov 25)No change to previous policy.  As all precautionary measures have now been lifted in all prefectures, schools have all resumed in-person learning at full capacity due to measures being lifted. Schools are to continue undergoing stringent sanitation and infection prevention measures, increased ventilation measures, and distribute rapid antigen test kits. Students with illness symptoms are not to attend schools. Individual schools may also have the jurisdiction to close due to in-school outbreaks on a school-by-school basis.  Schools have also resumed all club activities, events, and excursions; however strict infection control measures must be followed.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211213150916/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008192307/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211005/k10013291931000.html (school measures)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211130012156/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/1009757/1020631.html (Tokyo basic measures from Dec 1)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211130012221/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/1009757/1020626.html (Tokyo basic gathering measures from Dec 1)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211130012732/https://www.pref.okinawa.lg.jp/site/chijiko/koho/corona/documents/1125hoshin_1.pdf (Okinawa basic measures from Nov 25)

No change to previous policy. Third doses continue being administered to healthcare workers. The government is targeting a total of 1.04 million medical staff in December. On December 15, Moderna was also been approved to be administered half-dose as a booster shot.    Municipal and prefectural inoculation centres continue to be available for all those 12+ who wish to receive their first or second dose of the vaccine.  Children age 5-11 in Japan will likely begin vaccinations in February 2022 once approval has been completed.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211217045216/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/special/coronavirus/vaccine/japan_2021/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211217045823/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211216/k10013390701000.html (evidence of third doses being administered to health workers)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211217045509/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211216/k10013390451000.html (Moderna approval)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211203031729/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211201/k10013369451000.html (priority for third doses)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211202173408/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211202/k10013370651000.html (vaccines for 5-11)No change to previous policy. Masks should also be worn in schools by students and faculty members, and should only be removed when eating or partaking in physical activities.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211217023048/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211217041833/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/0000121431_00094.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211217041936/https://www.mext.go.jp/a_menu/coronavirus/mext_00020.htmlAs a result of Tokyo Metropolitan Area doubling their contact tracing staff to 3500 workers, Tokyo has been comprehensively follow up on all cases, particularly those who test positive for the omicron variant. As all precautionary measures have now been lifted in all prefectures, schools have all resumed in-person learning at full capacity due to measures being lifted. Schools are to continue undergoing stringent sanitation and infection prevention measures, increased ventilation measures, and distribute rapid antigen test kits. Students with illness symptoms are not to attend schools. Individual schools may also have the jurisdiction to close due to in-school outbreaks on a school-by-school basis, as seen in an elementary school in Nagaoka City, Niigata, which will temporarily close for the week after a cluster of positive cases were investigated (December 13).  Schools have also resumed all club activities, events, and excursions; however strict infection control measures must be followed.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211217023048/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211217044022/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/lnews/niigata/20211214/1030019312.html (evidence of temporary school closure in Niigata)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008192307/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211005/k10013291931000.html (school measures)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211130012156/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/1009757/1020631.html (Tokyo basic measures from Dec 1)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211130012221/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/1009757/1020626.html (Tokyo basic gathering measures from Dec 1)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211130012732/https://www.pref.okinawa.lg.jp/site/chijiko/koho/corona/documents/1125hoshin_1.pdf (Okinawa basic measures from Nov 25)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211217023544/https://www.pref.okinawa.lg.jp/site/chijiko/koho/corona/documents/1206english.pdf (EN - Okinawa basic measures from Nov 25)

No changes in policy, however testing capacities are being expanded. https://archive.fo/tKJ4INo changes in policy. https://archive.fo/tKJ4INo changes in policy. https://archive.fo/tKJ4INo changes in policy. https://archive.fo/tKJ4INo changes in policy. https://archive.fo/tKJ4INo changes in policy. https://archive.fo/tKJ4INo changes in policy. https://archive.fo/tKJ4I

On December 21, the Prime Minister of Japan announces the country will shorten the interval from the second dose for those to become eligible for a third dose. The interval has been shortened from 8 months to 6 months and elderly people nationwide are expected to begin third dose vaccinations beginning February.    https://archive.fo/MVZoM  https://archive.fo/JQ3JUContact tracing in Tokyo continues to be conducted, particularly for close contacts of those who have tested positive for the omicron variant. For note, are following up with a total of 1044 contacts and their family members for testing after an exposure to a traveller who had tested positive.    https://archive.fo/w3fnT  https://archive.fo/iqb1g

In response to the federal government shortening third dose intervals to 6 months from an individual's second dose, third dose vaccination began on December 23 for the elderly population in Sagamihara and Yokohama cities.    https://archive.fo/frlsIBeginning December 23, free PCR testing are being made available for those who are unable to be vaccinated before year-end and ahead of the New Year holidays. To be eligible for free testing, individuals must have a certificate citing inability to be vaccinated for health reasons or if an individual is under the age of 12 and under (who have not yet been approved vaccination). This free testing will be available until the end of March 2022.    On December 23, Prime Minister Kishida has given local governments the go ahead to allow for asymptomatic testing during possible exposure events as a means to control for the omicron variant.    https://archive.fo/NMdYa  https://archive.fo/vaHJw

In Osaka Prefecture and Tokyo Metropolitan Area, as a result of the discovery of the first cases of community-acquired omicron variant, free asymptomatic testing will become available to all residents beginning December 24 and 25. By December 27th, free testing will be expanded to over 30,000 assessement centres and pharmacies in Tokyo. Individuals have the option of being tested by either a free PCR testing (results within the same day) or a rapid antigen testing (results obtained in 10 mins). Local government recommends all positive test results to be reported to a medical institution for further follow up.    https://archive.fo/ZpbXV

Following Tokyo and Osaka, Okinawa is offering free asymptomatic PCR testing at public and private facilities to all residents of the prefecture from December 25.  On December 26, Fukuoka Prefecture has also opened up free asymptomatic testing to all residents. This announcement comes shortly after a community-acquired case for the omicron variant was reported in Fukuoka.  Tokyo will continue to offer free PCR testing to all individuals until January 31, 2022.    https://archive.fo/ZpbXV (Osaka & Tokyo)  https://archive.fo/v9SBG (Fukuoka)  https://archive.fo/JyBLE (Tokyo evidence)  https://archive.fo/7Tqmf (Tokyo evidence)  https://web.archive.org/web/20220108013217/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220104/k10013414281000.html (Okinawa evidence)  https://web.archive.org/web/20220108013225/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/1009757/1020775.html (Tokyo)

No change to previous policy. Due to the omicron variant, all international travel controls are to continue after December 31st and into the new year.  Japan continues to prohibit entry for non-Visa and leisure travel from all countries. Limited Visas are being processed and all incoming flights into the country are restricted to only 3,500 people in total per day.   Japan will also be extending the quarantine period at accommodation facilities for a number of additional countries.    https://archive.fo/fMpQs  https://web.archive.org/web/20211213152325/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211203/k10013374241000.html  https://archive.fo/dhNu9  https://archive.fo/5nIhA

Despite increasing cases, schools continue to remain open.  Schools are to continue undergoing stringent sanitation and infection prevention measures, increased ventilation measures, and distribute rapid antigen test kits. Students with illness symptoms are not to attend schools. Individual schools may also have the jurisdiction to close due to in-school outbreaks on a school-by-school basis.  Schools have also resumed all club activities, events, and excursions; however strict infection control measures must be followed.    https://archive.fo/yw3cF (Japan emergency measures)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008192307/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211005/k10013291931000.html (school measures)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211130012156/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/1009757/1020631.html (Tokyo basic measures from Dec 1)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211130012221/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/1009757/1020626.html (Tokyo basic gathering measures from Dec 1)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211130012732/https://www.pref.okinawa.lg.jp/site/chijiko/koho/corona/documents/1125hoshin_1.pdf (Okinawa basic measures from Nov 25)  https://archive.fo/PdDnLThere continues to be no change to previous policy. All public events have resumed. The government has provided detailed guidelines on infection control measures to reduce risk of outbreaks, including providing separate entrances and exits, and limiting personnel depending on venue capacity.    https://archive.fo/yw3cF (Japan emergency measures)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008192307/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211005/k10013291931000.html (school measures)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211130012156/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/1009757/1020631.html (Tokyo basic measures from Dec 1)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211130012221/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/1009757/1020626.html (Tokyo basic gathering measures from Dec 1)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211130012732/https://www.pref.okinawa.lg.jp/site/chijiko/koho/corona/documents/1125hoshin_1.pdf (Okinawa basic measures from Nov 25)  https://archive.fo/PdDnLNo change to previous policy.  For events with no loud cheering/shouting, a maximum of 5000 people are permitted to attend up to a venue's full capacity.  For events with loud cheering/shouting, gatherings may occur up to half a venue's capacity.    https://archive.fo/yw3cF (Japan emergency measures)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008192307/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211005/k10013291931000.html (school measures)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211130012156/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/1009757/1020631.html (Tokyo basic measures from Dec 1)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211130012221/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/1009757/1020626.html (Tokyo basic gathering measures from Dec 1)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211130012732/https://www.pref.okinawa.lg.jp/site/chijiko/koho/corona/documents/1125hoshin_1.pdf (Okinawa basic measures from Nov 25)  https://archive.fo/PdDnLThe government continues to encourage people to avoid dense crowds and situations of high risk for infection, to refrain for unnecessary movement to areas with high infection rates.    https://archive.fo/yw3cF (Japan emergency measures)The government continues to encourage residents to practice precautions moving between prefectures, particularly to and from areas of high infection rates and particularly for those unvaccinated.    https://archive.fo/yw3cF (Japan emergency measures)No change to previous policy. New unemployment subsidy application deadlines for January-March 2022 have been set for June 30, 2022 (support document revised as of Dec 23rd).  The Japan Ministry of Health, Labour, and Welfare continues to provide financial support in the forms of: employment subsidies to encourage business owners to maintain employees, leave of absence due to COVID-19 infection, living expenses for leave of absence or the unemployed, and special support for low-income child-rearing households for a maximum of 50,000 yen per child. Employment subsidies have a maximum of 15,000 yen per day per person.    https://archive.fo/HTePONo change to previous policy. New debt relief subsidy application deadlines for January-March 2022 have been set for June 30, 2022 (support document revised as of Dec 23rd).  The Japan Ministry of Health, Labour, and Welfare continues to provide debt relief: loans for small-lot emergency funds and comprehensive unemployment funds are provided at interest-free and payments may be deferred up to one year. Housing security loans are available for those at risk of losing housing: rent payments may be deferred up to 9-months with evidence of employment search. Property tax exemption may be available for applicants facing declining income or unemployment due to the pandemic. For single-parent households, family housing support loan of upto 40,000 yen for 12 months is available interest-free for a one-time redemption if the parent continues to work for a year. Interviews for single-parent households will be conducted to understand their living conditions, motivation for employment, efforts to acquire qualifications, etc. A policy is also in place for the deferment for payments of national taxes.    https://archive.fo/HTePOComprehensive public information about COVID-19 continues to be disseminated by the government.    https://archive.fo/Qm0IZ  https://archive.fo/6jEXKIn Tokyo, of the 25 people tested positive for the omicron strain, 11 had no history of travel and were community-acquired infections. Tokyo is expecting rapid increase in omicron cases as a result of the year-end holidays.    https://archive.fo/OldDNNo change to previous policy. The wearing of facial masks in Japan is wide spread and continues to be recommended by the government. Masks should also be worn in schools by students and faculty members, and should only be removed when eating or partaking in physical activities.    https://archive.fo/yw3cF (Japan emergency measures)

While Tokyo and Osaka has increase resources for contact tracing, due to rapidly rising cases, Naha has announced effective January 4th, close contact tracing will temporarily be focused on high risk settings such as medical institutions and elderly or welfare facilities.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220116210406/https://ryukyushimpo.jp/news/entry-1449967.html

On January 7, Okinawa Prefecture begins to distribute school attendance to reduce the spread of infection. Schools will be divided into groups and attend in-person on certain days of the week while attending remote learning on alternate days.    As a result of high case counts, the prefectures, Okinawa, Hiroshima, and Yamaguchi will implement priority countermeasures beginning January 9, 2022 (until 31st).    https://web.archive.org/web/20220108012250/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220107/k10013418911000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220108010037/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/As a result of high case counts, the prefectures, Okinawa, Hiroshima, and Yamaguchi will implement priority countermeasures beginning January 9, 2022 (until 31st). These measures include closing restaurants and retail from 8/9PM and to refrain from serving alcohol. Upper limit for event gatherings will also be limited to a maximum of 5,000 or half of the venue's capacity, whichever is the smallest number of attendees.  From January 11, 2022 in Tokyo (until 31st), restaurants certified by the local government may continue to serve patrons up to a limit of 8 people per table. Vaccination certificate app should be used on groups with more than 5 people. For stores not certified by the city, they will limit customers to 4 people per group and close by 9PM.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220108010037/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220108012419/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220107/k10013420601000.html (gatherings in Okinawa, Hiroshima, Yamaguchi)  https://web.archive.org/web/20220108012611/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220105/k10013416701000.html (stores in Okinawa, Hiroshima, Yamaguchi)  https://web.archive.org/web/20220108012952/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220107/k10013419911000.html (stores in Tokyo)As a result of high case counts, the prefectures, Okinawa, Hiroshima, and Yamaguchi will implement priority countermeasures beginning January 9, 2022 (until 31st). Tokyo begin restrictions in response to the omicron variant on January 11 and to continue until the 31st.  Measures require closing restaurants and retail from 9PM and to refrain from serving alcohol after 8PM. Restaurants may continue to serve patrons up to a limit of 4 people per table. For all other businesses remote work from home is encouraged when possible.  Upper limit for event gatherings will also be limited to a maximum of 5,000 or half of the venue's capacity, whichever is the smallest number of attendees. Loud events may only operate at 50% venue capacity, all other events may operate at 100% venue capacity.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220117173206/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/1009757/1020813.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220117173135/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/1009757/1020626.htmlTokyo begin restrictions in response to the omicron variant on January 11 and to continue until the 31st. Events may continue to go ahead. Upper limit for event gatherings will be limited to a maximum of 5,000 or half of the venue's capacity, whichever is the smallest number of attendees. Loud events may only operate at 50% venue capacity, all other events may operate at 100% venue capacity.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220117173206/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/1009757/1020813.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220117173135/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/1009757/1020626.html

In Okinawa and Hiroshima prefectures, with rising cases and insufficient personnel, standard contact tracing have also been suspended and contact tracing efforts have instead been focused on infections within hospitals, long-term care, and clusters within high risk groups.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220116210406/https://ryukyushimpo.jp/news/entry-1449967.html

No change to previous policy.  Japan continues to prohibit entry for non-Visa and leisure travel from all countries. Limited Visas are being processed and all incoming flights into the country are restricted to only 3,500 people in total per day.   Japan will also be extending the quarantine period at accommodation facilities for a number of additional countries.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211213152325/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211203/k10013374241000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220123220324/https://jp.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220123220655/https://www.anzen.mofa.go.jp/info/pcwideareaspecificinfo_2022C006.htmlNo change to previous policy. New unemployment subsidy application deadlines for January-March 2022 have been set for June 30, 2022 (support document revised as of Dec 23rd).  The Japan Ministry of Health, Labour, and Welfare continues to provide financial support in the forms of: employment subsidies to encourage business owners to maintain employees, leave of absence due to COVID-19 infection, living expenses for leave of absence or the unemployed, and special support for low-income child-rearing households for a maximum of 50,000 yen per child. Employment subsidies have a maximum of 15,000 yen per day per person.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220123220658/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/covid-19/kurashiyashigoto.htmlNo change to previous policy. New debt relief subsidy application deadlines for January-March 2022 have been set for June 30, 2022 (support document revised as of Dec 23rd).  The Japan Ministry of Health, Labour, and Welfare continues to provide debt relief: loans for small-lot emergency funds and comprehensive unemployment funds are provided at interest-free and payments may be deferred up to one year. Housing security loans are available for those at risk of losing housing: rent payments may be deferred up to 9-months with evidence of employment search. Property tax exemption may be available for applicants facing declining income or unemployment due to the pandemic. For single-parent households, family housing support loan of upto 40,000 yen for 12 months is available interest-free for a one-time redemption if the parent continues to work for a year. Interviews for single-parent households will be conducted to understand their living conditions, motivation for employment, efforts to acquire qualifications, etc. A policy is also in place for the deferment for payments of national taxes.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220123220658/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/covid-19/kurashiyashigoto.htmlComprehensive public information about COVID-19 continues to be disseminated by the government.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220123220935/https://corona.go.jp/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220123221001/https://corona.go.jp/dashboard/No change to previous policy.  Tokyo, Osaka, Okinawa, Fukuoka continues to offer free asymptomatic PCR testing at public and private facilities to all residents of the prefecture.  Tokyo will continue to offer free PCR testing to all individuals until January 31, 2022.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220117175016/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220108/k10013421271000.html (Okinawa evidence)  https://archive.fo/ZpbXV (Osaka & Tokyo)  https://archive.fo/v9SBG (Fukuoka)  https://archive.fo/JyBLE (Tokyo evidence)  https://archive.fo/7Tqmf (Tokyo evidence)  https://web.archive.org/web/20220108013217/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220104/k10013414281000.html (Okinawa evidence)  https://web.archive.org/web/20220108013225/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/1009757/1020775.html (Tokyo)In Tokyo, Fukuoka prefecture, and Sapporo, due to significant increase in cases, resources for close contact tracing have also begun prioritizing those in high risk institutions such as medical centres and long term care homes. This is in addition to limited contact tracing in Okinawa and Hiroshima.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220123221611/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220120/k10013439931000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220123221613/https://www.pref.fukuoka.lg.jp/contents/jyuutenka.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220123221813/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/sapporo-news/20220120/7000042505.htmlNo change to previous policy. For Miyazaki City and Nobeoka City, where the number of infected people is increasing recently, except for work and school, local governments are requesting residents refrain from going out of the home outside work and school purposes.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220207205418/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220207232751/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220201/k10013459791000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220128045726/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220125/k10013449331000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220120163925/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220119/k10013438191000.htmlThe government continues to encourage residents to practice precautions moving between prefectures, particularly to and from areas of high infection rates and particularly for those unvaccinated. No change to previous policy. New unemployment subsidy application deadlines for January-March 2022 have been set for June 30, 2022 (support document partially revised as of Jan 28 2022).  The Japan Ministry of Health, Labour, and Welfare continues to provide financial support in the forms of: employment subsidies to encourage business owners to maintain employees, leave of absence due to COVID-19 infection, living expenses for leave of absence or the unemployed, and special support for low-income child-rearing households for a maximum of 50,000 yen per child. Employment subsidies have a maximum of 15,000 yen per day per person.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220211190020/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/covid-19/kurashiyashigoto.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220211190012/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/content/10900000/000622924.pdfNo change to previous policy. New debt relief subsidy application deadlines for January-March 2022 have been set for June 30, 2022 (support document partially revised as of Jan 28 2022).  The Japan Ministry of Health, Labour, and Welfare continues to provide debt relief: loans for small-lot emergency funds and comprehensive unemployment funds are provided at interest-free and payments may be deferred up to one year. Housing security loans are available for those at risk of losing housing: rent payments may be deferred up to 9-months with evidence of employment search. Property tax exemption may be available for applicants facing declining income or unemployment due to the pandemic. For single-parent households, family housing support loan of upto 40,000 yen for 12 months is available interest-free for a one-time redemption if the parent continues to work for a year. Interviews for single-parent households will be conducted to understand their living conditions, motivation for employment, efforts to acquire qualifications, etc. A policy is also in place for the deferment for payments of national taxes.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220211190020/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/covid-19/kurashiyashigoto.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220211190012/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/content/10900000/000622924.pdfComprehensive public information about COVID-19 continues to be disseminated by the government.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220211190229/https://corona.go.jp/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220211190253/https://corona.go.jp/dashboard/To reduce burden on medical facilities due increasing cases and the number of people looking to get tested, Tokyo Metropolitan Government has begun sending antigen test kits to those who apply and identify as close contacts of recently diagnosed cases.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220209115924/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220208/k10013472791000.html

No change to previous policy. The government continues to encourage people to avoid dense crowds and situations of high risk for infection, to refrain for unnecessary movement to areas with high infection rates. Telework is also highly encouraged.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220225195546/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/The government continues to encourage residents to practice precautions moving between prefectures, particularly to and from areas of high infection rates and particularly for those unvaccinated.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220225195546/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/No change to previous policy. New unemployment subsidy application deadlines for January-March 2022 have been set for June 30, 2022 (support document partially revised as of Jan 28 2022).  The Japan Ministry of Health, Labour, and Welfare continues to provide financial support in the forms of: employment subsidies to encourage business owners to maintain employees, leave of absence due to COVID-19 infection, living expenses for leave of absence or the unemployed, and special support for low-income child-rearing households for a maximum of 50,000 yen per child. Employment subsidies have a maximum of 15,000 yen per day per person.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220211190020/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/covid-19/kurashiyashigoto.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220211190012/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/content/10900000/000622924.pdfNo change to previous policy. New debt relief subsidy application deadlines for January-March 2022 have been set for June 30, 2022 (support document partially revised as of Jan 28 2022).  The Japan Ministry of Health, Labour, and Welfare continues to provide debt relief: loans for small-lot emergency funds and comprehensive unemployment funds are provided at interest-free and payments may be deferred up to one year. Housing security loans are available for those at risk of losing housing: rent payments may be deferred up to 9-months with evidence of employment search. Property tax exemption may be available for applicants facing declining income or unemployment due to the pandemic. For single-parent households, family housing support loan of upto 40,000 yen for 12 months is available interest-free for a one-time redemption if the parent continues to work for a year. Interviews for single-parent households will be conducted to understand their living conditions, motivation for employment, efforts to acquire qualifications, etc. A policy is also in place for the deferment for payments of national taxes.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220211190020/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/covid-19/kurashiyashigoto.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220211190012/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/content/10900000/000622924.pdfComprehensive public information about COVID-19 continues to be disseminated by the government.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220225200557/https://corona.go.jp/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220225200630/https://corona.go.jp/dashboard/No change to previous policy. In Yokohama, rapid antigen test kits are also being sent out to relieve strain on PCR testing due to staff shortages at hospitals and health lab facilities.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220225201303/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220222/k10013496881000.html

The Tokyo Metropolitan Government has extended the "rebound alert period" by about one month to prevent the spread of the new coronavirus infection. The rebound alert period involves relaxing the use of restaurants from four people per group to eight people per group from April 24 2022 to May 22 2022. Groups are permitted to remain in restaurants for a maximum of 2 hours.  For uncertified restaurants, there remains a limit of a maximum number of people to 4 per group, stay for 2 hours, in addition to only serving alcoholic beverages before 9pm.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220426024011/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220425051456/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220421/k10013593001000.html

For the duration of the Golden Week holidays (April 29 2022, May3-6 2022), prefectures across Japan are offering free asymptomatic PCR and rapid antigen testing from April 28 to May 8 2022. For instance, Tokyo will have 870 venues and 5 major metro stations offering testing for many people looking to travel and visiting family during the long week-long holidays. Government of Japan is looking to relax border restrictions to allow out-of-country tourists and increase daily inbound travellers from 10,000 per day to 20,000 per day. Prime Minister Kishida announced next month that he would ease the entry to the same level as the other G7 countries. However, due to the strain on the quarantine system and thus exceptions for certain inbound travellers will likely apply. On May 23, 2022, the rebound alert period set by the Tokyo Metropolitan Government has been lifted. The measures involved restricting groups within restaurants to a maximum of 8 people and 2 hours.  From May 23rd, basic measures were put in place for Tokyo Metropolitan Area. These measures for uncertified restaurants continue to involve limiting a maximum number of people to 4 per group, stay for 2 hours, in addition to only serving alcoholic beverages before 9pm.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220531010302/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/1009757/1021584.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220520133826/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/_res/projects/default_project/_page_/001/021/584/20220520/20220520.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20220531010249/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/1009757/1021586.htmlOn May 23, 2022, the Japanese government no longer recommends face masks for children age 2 and younger. For preschool children over the age of 2, social distancing is no longer recommended to allow social development. In schools, masks are also not required during physical activity, including outdoor playgrounds, indoor gymnasiums, and indoor swimming pools.  For everyone else, face masks are no longer recommended outdoors if little conversation is being conducted, even if physical distancing cannot be maintained. In the summer, face mask removal is recommended to prevent over heating. Face masks are still recommended for indoor spaces however.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220531003902/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220526102255/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220524/k10013641941000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220525004517/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220523/k10013639521000.html

On May 24, 2022, pilot tour groups of about 50 people from the United States, Australia, Thailand, and Singapore involving travellers who have been vaccinated three times have been permitted as foreign tourists into the country.  The government will be announcing broader plans to accept more tourists from other countries in the coming days. However, so far, only tourists on package tours with authorized tour guides are permitted.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220531005200/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220524/k10013640691000.html

On May 26, 2022, the Prime Minister of Japan announces that beginning June 10, 2022, Japan will be permitting entry of foreign tourists from 98 countries which have been considered lowest risk for COVID-19 infections. However, for the time being, only travellers with authorized tour guides/conductors will be permitted.   More information about vaccination status will be coming: beginning June 10th, for travellers entering from 98 lowest risk countries, testing and quarantining will not be required even if travellers have not been vaccinated. For 99 other countries (including India and Vietnam), travellers are exempt from testing and 3-day quarantine period if they have been vaccinated 3 times. For travellers coming from Pakistan, Fiji, Albania, and Sierra Leone, travellers will be required to quarantine on entry.    Japan will also be increasing the upper limit of inbound travellers from the current 10,000 to 20,000 people from June 1, 2022.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220528015505/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220526/k10013645131000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220531011450/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220527/k10013645231000.html    https://web.archive.org/web/20220531005200/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220524/k10013640691000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220531003926/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220519/k10013632471000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220531013225/https://jp.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220531013404/https://www.mofa.go.jp/mofaj/ca/fna/page4_005130.html

No change to previous policy. Extensive employment and income support due to the pandemic continues to be offered to citizens. Information on registration has been updated as of June 9, 2022.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220614012233/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/content/10900000/000622924.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20220530211306/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/covid-19/kurashiyashigoto.htmlNo change to previous policy. Extensive debt support due to the pandemic continues to be offered to citizens. Information on registration has been updated as of June 9, 2022.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220614012233/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/content/10900000/000622924.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20220530211306/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/covid-19/kurashiyashigoto.html

On June 1, 2022, Japan increases their inbound traveller limit from 10,000 people to 20,000 people per day. At the present time, Japan continues to only allow travel through guided tours from their pilot program involving the United States, Australia, and Singapore. All travellers are required to be vaccinated if they travel as a part of the pilot program. In addition, 98 countries deemed as low-risk will not be required to quarantine or present an antigen test regardless of their vaccination status. In the next risk-level, 99 countries will waive their quarantine and test requirements on the condition of being vaccinated with 3 doses.    Beginning June 10, 2022, Japan will permit leisure travel for all countries, as long as travellers come as a part of an authorized tour guide. Depending on the country of origin, unvaccinated visitors may enter provided they complete restrictions at the time of entry including the necessary quarantine period.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220611183656/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220601/k10013652011000.html

On June 10, 2022, restrictions on foreign tourism has been lifted for all countries. For the time being however, all tourists must come with an authorized tour guide or tour company.  For 98 countries deemed as lowest risk, travellers are exempt for additional entry restrictions including screening and quarantine periods even if travellers are unvaccinated.  For 99 countries at the next lowest risk level, travellers are exempt from screening and quarantine period provided they have received 3 doses of the COVID-19 vaccine.  Lastly, there are 4 countries in the highest risk group, these travellers are subjected to mandatory PCR testing and quarantine period on entry.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220611183656/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220601/k10013652011000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220612032923/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220610/k10013665671000.html

Despite rising number of infections in Japan, the government has said no additional restrictive measures will be announced at this time and the focus will be on economic recovery.  The government has therefore shortened the self-isolation period for COVID-positive individuals from 7-days down to 5-days. If an individual already tests negative via rapid antigen tests, the number of self-isolation can be shortened down to 3-days.  Schools should continue to observe caution and have the jurisdiction to individually close or cancel extracurricular activities if outbreaks should occur.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220725221141/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220724070329/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220724/k10013733271000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220725221232/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220722/k10013730581000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220725220305/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220722/k10013731671000.htmlDespite rising number of infections in Japan, the government has said additional no restrictive measures will be announced at this time and the focus will be on economic recovery.  The government has therefore shortened the self-isolation period for COVID-positive individuals from 7-days down to 5-days. If an individual already tests negative via rapid antigen tests, the number of self-isolation can be shortened down to 3-days.  Basic measures continue to be in place for Tokyo Metropolitan Area. These measures for uncertified restaurants continue to involve limiting a maximum number of people to 4 per group, stay for 2 hours, in addition to only serving alcoholic beverages before 9pm. These same measures have been extended to Okinawa prefecture.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220725221141/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220725221023/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220721/k10013729971000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220724070329/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220724/k10013733271000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220725221232/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220722/k10013730581000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220725220305/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220722/k10013731671000.htmlEvents should continue to follow recommendations for infection control. Depending on the country (as provided by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs), unvaccinated travellers may be required to quarantine. In June, the number of foreign tourists visiting Japan exceeded 120,000, exceeding 100,000 for the third consecutive month. Acceptance of foreign tourists has resumed since June, and the Japan Tourism Agency expects that the number of tourists entering the country will increase further.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220725220303/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220720/k10013728141000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220611183656/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220601/k10013652011000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220612032923/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220610/k10013665671000.htmlRT-PCR testing continue to be limited for symptomatic individuals as deemed by a doctor and patients who present to hospital. On July 29 2022, the government announces that prefectures will independently issue their own countermeasures against BA.5 based on prefectural burden on medical institutions (i.e. hospital bed occupancy). Tokyo Metropolitan Government has also announced until at least August 21st, individuals are recommended to wear masks in outdoor gatherings and maintain distance in crowds. From August 5-18, free testing stations will also be set up at various metro/train stations. The city will also be distributing free rapid antigen test kits to those who test positive and their close contacts.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220806225213/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220729/k10013742201000.html https://web.archive.org/web/20220807221530/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220729/k10013742621000.htmlOn July 29 2022, the government announces that prefectures will independently issue their own countermeasures against BA.5 based on prefectural burden on medical institutions (i.e. hospital bed occupancy).    https://web.archive.org/web/20220806225213/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220729/k10013742201000.htmlOn July 29 2022, the government announces that prefectures will independently issue their own countermeasures against BA.5 based on prefectural burden on medical institutions (i.e. hospital bed occupancy). In Tokyo and Osaka, free PCR testing and rapid antigen testing stations have been set up to allow residents to test before returning to hometowns in the countryside and gathering during summer breaks.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220808234312/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220802/k10013747391000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220806064134/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220805/k10013754821000.html

No change to previous policy, as individual schools have the jurisdiction to close and reopen based on each school's outbreak status.  During July 2022, there were 101 childcare centres nationwide that have closed as a result of positive tests within the facilities.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220808234201/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220803/k10013749971000.htmlTo lessen the burden on contact tracing efforts, Tokyo has begun allowing citizens to submit their positive infection results online.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220808234230/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220803/k10013750601000.html

The Japanese government is encouraging all residents to test for infection via PCR or rapid antigen tests before returning to ones' hometown to visit older family members for Obon festival occuring August 13-16 in 2022.   In Tokyo, testing has become free for all Tokyo residents ahead of Obon.  Lastly, the Ministry of Health has announced that bans on the sale and purchase of rapid antigen tests online has been lifted due to the increase in demand and increase in infections across the country.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220812095101/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220810/k10013764711000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220816034840/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220812/k10013766781000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220816034838/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220812/k10013766661000.htm

Okinawan government recommends people to exercise caution and in particular, to not visit the elderly during this time.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220830013529/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220816113333/https://www.pref.okinawa.lg.jp/site/chijiko/koho/corona/documents/sengen.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20220830013903/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/1009757/1021587.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220830014215/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp//1009757/1021586.htmlBeginning September 7 2022, Japan will reinstate restrictions for incoming travellers. All travellers including Japanese citizens must present a negative PCR test within 72-hours of arrival. Travellers are exempt for presenting a PCR test result if they have been vaccinated 3 times.  The government beginning September will also allow 50,000 visitors into the borders per day, up from the current 20,000 a day.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220828130721/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220824/k10013786051000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220829040723/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220824/k10013785261000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220830012933/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220824/k10013784651000.html

On 7 September 2022, restrictions on incoming travelers have been eased. Travelers will now not be required to travel on guided tours with a tour conductor, however they will still be required to book with an authorized agency package that will allow travelers to be contacted about potential exposures. Lastly, all travellers including Japanese citizens must present a negative PCR test within 72-hours of arrival unless they have been vaccinated 3-times.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220828130721/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220824/k10013786051000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220920034152/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220907/k10013806481000.html

Schools continue to exercise caution and have the jurisdiction to close based on outbreak status.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220927034430/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/As of September 13, Tokyo Metropolitan Government continues to recommend avoiding crowded areas and restricting non-certified restaurants to only serve parties of 4 or less, under 2 hours, and to serve alcohol between the times 11AM to 9PM.  Events nationwide also continue to be restricted to 50% capacity indoors for loud events or 5000 people.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220927034430/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220917063326/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/1009757/1022153.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220927034651/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/1009757/1022152.htmlAs of September 13, Tokyo Metropolitan Government continues to recommend avoiding crowded areas and restricting non-certified restaurants to only serve parties of 4 or less, under 2 hours, and to serve alcohol between the times 11AM to 9PM. Events nationwide also continue to be restricted to 50% capacity indoors for loud events or 5000 people.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220927034430/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220917063326/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/1009757/1022153.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220927034651/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/1009757/1022152.html

The government has announced further easing of restrictions for travelers will occur beginning October: limit on number of incoming travelers will be removed (currently the limit is 50,000 people per day), individuals will be allowed free movement (no longer require an authorized travel agency), and visas may be adjusted for short-term stays.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220920035802/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220916/k10013820001000.html

The Japanese government announces from 11 October 2022, Japan will lift international travel restrictions for non-Visa travel and lift daily limits on number of incoming travelers.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220926131138/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220922/k10013832571000.html

From 26 September 2022, a number of municipalities including the Tokyo Metropolitan Area begins to reduce publication of the number of infected people. In order to decrease burden on public health agencies and to simplify the tally, many regions including Tokyo will only report those of severe illness.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220927034243/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220926/k10013837861000.html

On 11 October 2022, Japan lifts policy restricting a maximum number of inbound travelers. In addition, travelers no longer require a Visa or an authorized travel agency to travel. However, screening continues to be in place: travelers who have received 3 doses against COVID-19 can travel with no restrictions; travelers who have received less than 3 doses must present a negative PCR test result within 72 hours.    https://web.archive.org/web/2/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20221011/k10013854251000.html

On 21 October 2022, The Ministry of Health, Labour, and Welfare announces they will be scaling back income subsidies that were implemented as a result of economic burdens caused by COVID-19. Subsidy rate will return to 50% from the current 75% for large companies and 67% for small and medium enterprises from 90%. More information is to follow later in the month of October.    https://web.archive.org/web/20221024231353/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20221021/k10013866791000.html
